[SEP] The Baixa is Lisbon’s principal business district. [SEP] The main square is the Praça Dom Pedro IV, better known as the Rossio. [SEP] Look out for the railway station, Estação do Rossio, which looks like a Moorish palace with horseshoe arches, just west of the square. [SEP] Two blocks north is another lively square,

[SEP] Although they were common at the time, this is now the only secret chapel left in the city, and because of its location in the house is called “Our Lord in the Attic” or Ons’ Lieve Heer op Solder. [SEP] Over its years of use as a church, three surrounding houses were added to create extra space, and several of the other rooms are furnished in authentic 18th-century style. [SEP] It is a fascinating glimpse of a very difficult time in Amsterdam’s history, but it’s not just a museum piece — the church is still used for weddings. [SEP] Southeast of Oude Kerk you will
column3: through the small Chinese Quarter to reach Waag. [SEP] This is one of the oldest buildings in the city and was opened in 1488 as a city gate, marking the eastern boundary of the city along the new wall built after the disastrous fire in the 1450s. [SEP] The numerous turrets and rounded tower give it the look of a fairytale castle but it has had a more colorful history. [SEP] Public executions were held here in the 16th century with the condemned being kept in a small cell on the ground floor before they met their fate. [SEP] From the early 17th century it became the weigh house (the name Waaggebouw means “weigh house”) for cargoes entering or leaving the city down the Geldersekade Canal to its north. [SEP] Wander through the square, which hosts an art market on Sundays, to reach Rembrandtsplein, one of the city’s most vibrant social centers. [SEP] Before 1878 this square was called Botermarkt, (a butter market was held here in the 19th century) but the square was renamed after the large statue of Rembrandt was sited here. [SEP] One wonders what he would have made of the square, for since the statue was unveiled, it has attracted theaters, cinemas, clubs, and show halls, along with a plethora of bars and restaurants and a curtain of vibrant neon signs all around the façade. [SEP] On a summer evening it is one of the best places to sit with a drink and watch the world go by, and is within easy reach of a romantic
column3: along the canalsides. [SEP] Beyond the eastern end of Waterlooplein you will see the Visserplein, busy with several lanes of traffic. [SEP] Head across the square to Weesperstraat to find the Joods Historisch Museum (Jewish Historical Museum) which documents the history of the once large and influential Jewish community in the city. [SEP] Jewish history dates back to the late 16th century, but was cut short by the Nazi occupation of Amsterdam in 1940. [SEP] The systematic deportation of the Jewish population to concentration camps destroyed the community and after the war only a handful of the thousands forced to leave returned to their homes.

column1: The Botanical Gardens have a long and illustrious history. [SEP] They began as a small medicinal garden in 1682, but soon became the depository for many of the new plant species brought from Dutch colonies in the Golden Age and were responsible for developing each genus for cultivation, propagation and commercial exploitation. [SEP] The distinctive glass houses were added in 1912, and today the gardens have one of the largest collections in the world. [SEP] A two-minute
column3: down Plantage Middenlaan (Plantage Middle Road) leads you to Artis, a fascinating complex of zoo, aquarium, planetarium, and Geological Museum which aims to increase your knowledge of the physical world. [SEP] The zoo was one of the first in Europe when it opened its doors in 1838, and it has continued as a groundbreaking institution, now acting as a center for efforts to save several endangered species of animals. [SEP] Many of the old and confined Victorian enclosures where the animals were kept have been redeveloped in the 1990s to create more fitting environments for their majestic and healthy-looking animals. [SEP] The Planetarium and other areas of Artis offer fun ways to learn about the world around us and are entertaining for adults and children alike.

column1: Some inhabitants get a bird’s eye view of Artis zoo — imagine looking out of your apartment window on a rainy Amsterdam day and seeing a small herd of grazing zebra. [SEP] Walk north through Entrepodok and you will reach the main route of Prinse Henrikkade which runs along the northern edge of the city (this would lead you back to central station if you turned left). [SEP] Cross the bridge of the Nieuwe Vaart canal and
column3: towards a large square building with a masted sail ship docked outside. [SEP] This is The Scheepvaartmuseum (The National Maritime Museum). [SEP] As you cross the bridge, look left for a glimpse of the only windmill left in the city’s central area. [SEP] The De Gooyer windmill was built in the early part of the 18th century to grind corn. [SEP] The building housing The Scheepvaartmuseum was built in 1656 for the Dutch navy. [SEP] Its strong walls safeguarded a vast arsenal used to protect Dutch interests around the known world. [SEP] Today its extensive exhibits document the long and illustrious history of maritime achievement by the Dutch, with paintings, maps, and maritime models explaining the part that ships — and particularly the VOC — played in the growth of the empire in the 17th cen

[SEP] Today its 46 hectares (120 acres) have grazing farm animals, flocks of parakeets, jogging tracks, and cycle paths. [SEP] It is the perfect place for a picnic on a summer’s day. [SEP] The large pavilion, which opened in 1881, was restored and refurbished in 1991 and reopened as the Nederlands Filmmuseum. [SEP] It now shows more than 1000 films each year including many outdoor screenings and other artistic performances in the summer. [SEP] Only five minutes to the south of Leidseplein is the museum quarter, for many visitors the raison d’être for their visit to Amsterdam. column3: from one to the next in a matter of moments. [SEP] Although all very different in appearance, they are brought together by an open space which has recently been redesigned and replanted to accent the buildings. column1: exhausted after your “museum-fest,” then the streets around the Museumplein offer some exciting retail therapy. [SEP] Walk across Paulus Potterstraat from the Van Gogh Museum and you will find Coster Diamonds, one of the oldest “houses” in the city, where you can watch diamonds being polished and maybe buy a carat or two. [SEP] Van Baerlstraat, bordering the west side of Museumplein, is the haute couture area of the city. [SEP] For further culture of a musical nature the Concertgebouw on Van Bearlstraat is home to the orchestra of the same name. [SEP] The main auditorium is considered to have almost perfect acoustics even though the designer of the building, Van Gendt, had no experience in this specialized area. [SEP] If you want to stroll back to town after your visit to the museums then

[SEP] Prices are said to be on the high side, but the dealers are some of the most experienced in the world and they are sure to give you good advice. [SEP] Walk north along the whole length of Nieuwe Speigalstraat and you will eventually reach Herengracht at its most spectacular point. [SEP] Extended several times, including a wing designed by de Keyser, it was opened as the Amsterdam Historical Museum in 1975 and its rooms reveal the details of the development of this fascinating city. [SEP] You’ll see plans, maps, and paintings depicting the streets and canals as they were when just completed. [SEP] The Golden Age is brought to life (rooms 5–15) but there is also an interesting section on 20th-century Amsterdam, the Nazi occupation, and efforts to protect and preserve the city. [SEP] Tiny details, such as the relief above the Kalverstraat entrance which asks people to support the upkeep of the orphanage, also point to the museum’s original purpose. [SEP] Another couple of minutes strolling will bring you to Dam Square (simply called Dam by Amsterdammers), the symbolic heart of the city. column1: Just 5 km (2.75 miles) beyond Monnickendam is the community of Marken, one of the most beautiful villages in the Netherlands and home to a community of Calvinist Dutch whose traditions reach back hundreds of years. [SEP] The older inhabitants of this close-knit community still wear traditional Dutch costume as everyday wear. [SEP] Until 1957 the village was situated on an island, remote from the outside world. [SEP] The opening of a roadway linking the village to the mainland brought many changes for the inhabitants. [SEP] Today Marken welcomes visitors but not their cars, which must be left in a large car park on the outskirts. [SEP] You can
column3: through the village with its traditional painted wooden houses to the picture-perfect port. [SEP] Stop at the tiny museum on the quayside, which holds an eclectic mix of seafaring and fishing memorabilia. [SEP] Traveling from Monnickendam to Marken, the road leads out into open water, home to hundreds of thousands of birds in the summer. [SEP] The native herons, ducks, and moorhens see many species of migratory birds who fly north for the summer and return south as winter approaches. [SEP] The resulting explosion badly damaged the structure and many other ancient buildings on the site. [SEP] The center of the Parthenon was totally destroyed along with many columns and priceless carved friezes. [SEP] Subsequent “licences” granted by the Ottomans to European nobles saw many prize friezes disappear to archaeological collections around Europe, including the Elgin marbles (ornately carved pediments) that were taken to London by Lord Elgin. [SEP] Walk around the 70 m (228 ft) by 30 m (101 ft) exterior to really appreciate the grace of the columns. [SEP] There are no straight lines anywhere in the building — the graduated curves simply create the illusion of the vertical and horizontal. [SEP] The Panathenian Festival Procession would start from here on its journey to the Acropolis, and the procession of the Eleusian Mysteries would leave from here through the Sacred Gate and along the Sacred Way. [SEP] Finds cover 7,000 years of Greek history, and have been brought from sites all across Greece. [SEP] The collection brings the ancient Greek world to life shedding light on almost every aspect of the daily activities of the citizens. [SEP] Prepare to spend at least two hours here, don’t try and rush this amazing collection. [SEP] The map of the museum issued with your ticket will be a great help in finding your way around the somewhat confusing array of rooms and corridors. [SEP] You are sure to find your own favorites, but here are a few acknowledged highlights. [SEP] In the prehistoric collection (rooms 3–6) enjoy the treasure-trove found a

The simple, rounded female figures were funerary or religious objects and are in total contrast to the intricate pediment and frieze carvings and religious statuary found at temples on the Acropolis and in the Acropolis Museum. [SEP] You’ll also see a rare male figure among the collection, and the beautiful Harp Player — a more complex carving in the same style. [SEP] Rooms 7–35 concentrate on sculpture — perhaps the greatest collection of ancient sculpture in the world — and these are displayed to show the chronological development of the art form. [SEP] Simply styled male and female figures (kouros and kore) of the Achaiac Age (seventh–fifth century b.c.) give way to more ornate and literal human forms as you
column3: through the collection into the Classical Age and then on to the Hellenistic and Roman eras. [SEP] Greek gods are popular themes, followed by eminent human figures of Roman times. [SEP] Room 7 holds the important early statue of Artemis by Nikandre of Naxos (c640 b.c.). [SEP] Room 15 is dominated by a fine statue of Poseidon in bronze (460 b.c.) found in the sea off the island of Euboea. [SEP] The god is set to launch his trident against foes unknown. [SEP] The Hall of the Stairs hosts another statue dredged from the sea, that of the Jockey of the Artemision. [SEP] The diminutive jockey drives on the handsome steed which has its two front legs raised into the air, as if about to leap over an invisible obstacle.

[SEP] Much of the permanent collection comprises 19th- and 20th-century Greek art and post-Byzantine icons, though you can also find works by El Greco, Picasso, and Delacroix. [SEP] From the National Gallery it is just a short

[SEP] Look for a dramatic modern sculpture in glass depicting a human figure running at an extremely high speed (or blown by the wind) that graces the main intersection here. column1: Lycabettus and Kolonaki To the west of the bare sheer rock of the Acropolis is a rival hill — the verdant pine-clad Lycabettus, which makes an inviting diversion from the archaeological sites of the city. [SEP] Here you’ll be able to sit in shade and listen to the birds. [SEP] The hill was never settled in ancient times because there was no water supply. [SEP] You can reach the upper slopes by funicular. [SEP] When you reach the top station,
column3: to the small chapels of Ayios Isidoros and Ayios Georgios — center of the Easter celebrations for the city — a modern amphitheater for summer performances, and wonderful views across Athens where major attractions are pointed out on marble panoramas. [SEP] Though there are fixed telescopes here, having your own binoculars is a boon to really take in the detail. [SEP] Surrounding the lower slopes of Lycabettus on the south and west sides is Kolonaki, perhaps the most fashionable district of central Athens. [SEP] Apartments and houses here are much sought after as they sit among chic boutiques, designer stores, restaurants, and bars. [SEP] It is one of the best parts of the city to eat out in the evening with a range of good international eateries in addition to traditional Greek tavernas.

column1: North from Zea harbor is another pretty harbor, Mikrolimani (Small Harbor) or Tourkolimani, where you’ll find the fishing fleet and some good fish tavernas. [SEP] Or head south towards the main historical attractions of Piraeus. [SEP] From the south side of Zea harbor it is only a short
column3: to the Archaeological Museum of Piraeus. [SEP] The rather dour building hides a treasure-trove of statuary and other artifacts found during excavation of the ancient shrines of the city, and communal buildings such as the Agora. [SEP] Pride of place goes to the Piraeus Kouros, the oldest full-size bronze figure depicting the god Apollo. [SEP] On the grounds of the museum are scant remains of the ancient Theater of Zea. [SEP] Walking further south along the promenade past remnants of the ancient sea wall brings you to another small bay where you will find the Hellenic Maritime Museum, a semicircular museum with small garden in front complete with cannon. [SEP] In ancient times the way was lined with shrines and tombs, which are now and again brought to light when redevelopment takes place. [SEP] Eleusis was home to the Sanctuary of Demeter and the Eleusian Mysteries — a series of complex and enigmatic rituals only performed by initiates of the order. [SEP] The order thrived from the Mycenaean era to the coming of Christianity. [SEP] Annual celebrations to Demeter took place in Athens each September, with a public festival and a secret religious rite that transformed chosen followers into initiates of the secrets. [SEP] A procession would leave Eleusis and
column3: along the Sacred Way entering Athens via the Sacred Gate at Kerameikos (see page 49) before proceeding to the Acropolis. [SEP] In Eleusis the sacred way led directly to the Sanctuary of Demeter and a large Temple of Artemis with a forecourt where the initiates would gather in preparation for the procession. [SEP] A great Propylaia marked the entrance to the town  — a copy of that at the Acropolis. [SEP] The Precinct of Demeter lay in a walled complex, and its inner sanctum, the Periklean Telesterion, where only initiates were allowed to enter, sat within the temple. [SEP] You will also find the remains of more mundane structures such as the Bouleuterion and gymnasium. [SEP] A museum on site displays extremely good artifacts found among the ruins.

column1: Vendue House, at the western end of Bay Street, at the corner of George Street, was once the site of the Nassau slave auction. [SEP] It now houses the Pompey Museum of Slavery and Emancipation. [SEP] The pale pink stone house is unassuming, but the interior tells of the plight of slaves on the islands and of the positive work that was undertaken in the years following emancipation. [SEP] The Pirates of Nassau attraction at the corner of George and Marlborough Streets brings to life the dramatic and exciting world of the pirates. [SEP] The building itself dates from the 18th century; the attraction inside recreates the Nassau quayside of the 17th century. [SEP] A three-quarter-size French corvette ship and quayside buildings have been stunningly brought to life. [SEP] As you
column3: along the “dock,” costumed staff act out the roles of shipmate and pirate and regale you with tales of their everyday lives and deeds. [SEP] Visitors then step inside the 75-ft- (23-m-) long vessel to examine the paraphernalia of the pirate’s trade that line the corridors and decks. [SEP] Treasure chests mix with rum casks, and pirates tell of their lives at sea in the lonely and dangerous times. [SEP] Listen to the groaning of injured pirates and witness the rudimentary and unsanitary surgical techniques that led to so many deaths — the ship’s carpenter doubled as surgeon. [SEP] Read about the crew’s diet of “salmagundi,” a stew of pickled herrings, meat, and eggs mixed with wine and vinegar, which served to both preserve the protein and disguise the taste. [SEP] The hotels here have all the luxuries you could ever need, yet you might feel as if you’re a million miles away from the worries of the world. [SEP] The cay is small enough to explore on foot but most people choose to rent a golf cart or bicycle (your hotel can make the arrangements). [SEP] New Plymouth is the largest town on the cay. [SEP] In the 16th century the Spaniards sank a well here to supply their treasure fleets with fresh water for the long journey back across the Atlantic. column1: Once a magnet for foreign artists and still home to some, Ubud and the cluster of villages around it form the cultural and artistic focus of Bali. [SEP] An increasing number of visitors come on day trips from the coastal resorts, but a better plan is to stay overnight or longer. [SEP] There’s a wide choice of accommodations, ranging from cheap homestays and charming middle range hotels to high-priced luxury hideaways in the countryside just outside Ubud. [SEP] Day trippers only get to see the commercialism and chaos in Ubud’s main streets. [SEP] Just a short
column3: away, however, you’re among the green, peaceful rice terraces and jungle-filled river gorges that have captivated Bali’s visitors for decades and are so much a part of the region’s legendary mystique. [SEP] For schedules of dance performances and other events in the vicinity, pay an early visit to the Bina Wisata information office on Jalan Raya. [SEP] Excellent, very inexpensive performances of traditional dance are offered in the atmospheric compound beside the palace in the center of town. [SEP] In addition to its many shops, markets, and galleries, Ubud is home to a number of interesting museums.

column1: Peliatan is known for its dances and gamelan music as well as painting and carving — “parasite carvings” (see page 92) are a recent specialty. [SEP] The Agung Rai Gallery sells some of the best and most expensive modern Balinese paintings. [SEP] At Pengosekan, just a short
column3: farther south, the painters concentrate on images of birds and butterflies in idyllic “Garden of Eden” landscapes. [SEP] The recently opened Agung Rai Museum of Art displays Indonesian and European paintings. [SEP] East of Ubud

[SEP] Today, tour groups come for short stays and, as everywhere in Bali, standards and prices are steadily going up. [SEP] Actually, Lovina is not one village but a string of small ones, starting 6 km (4 miles) west of Singaraja and continuing for 10 km (6 miles) up the coast road. [SEP] Shops, restaurants, and moneychangers are scattered along the busy stretch. [SEP] The beach itself is shallow and gently shelving, making it an ideal place for small children. [SEP] There is calm water on the inside of the reef and good snorkeling over it. [SEP] Lovina’s dark sand is less inviting than the white or golden variety at the southern resorts, and gets too hot to
column3: on in bare feet in the middle of the day. [SEP] Dawn and dusk are the best times for the beach. [SEP] Dolphins frolic offshore almost every morning — boats will take you out to see them up close. [SEP] At sunset, the fishermen prepare for a night’s work aided by batteries of lights on the boats to attract their catch, while local farmers herd their goats or lead their water buffaloes along the sand. [SEP] If you’re lucky, you may be around to see the races between beautifully decorated pairs of water buffaloes pulling a sled around a track in the fields. [SEP] Ask if any are scheduled: They follow the Balinese calendar.

[SEP] Guides and porters can be hired by the day, and you can buy basic food and rent camping gear, including tents. [SEP] Take water-purifying tablets, warm clothes, and arrange for a small camping stove. [SEP] The main objective of most trekkers is the awesome crater with its big C-shaped lake. column1: East of Narmada, near the main road that runs through Lombok, there is a cluster of craft villages. [SEP] The baskets and tablemats from Loyok are famous throughout Indonesia. [SEP] In neighboring Rungkang, they make smooth jet-black pots of all sizes and then weave a fine basket to fit tightly around them, using supple lengths of ultra-thin rattan. [SEP] On the southern slopes of Gunung Rinjani, Tete Batu is a favorite local retreat, with an old hotel and a couple of homestays. [SEP] Here you can
column3: to forest waterfalls, while the black monkeys chatter, squeal, and swing in the trees. [SEP] Labuhan Lombok is a hot, windswept, dusty, end-of-the-world sort of spot, in spite of its picturesque stilt houses. [SEP] From here, ferries laden with cars, motorbikes, and passengers sail several times a day eastward to the island of Sumbawa from a terminal 3 km (2 miles) from the village.

[SEP] Schilling (Ferran, [SEP] 23) draws a smoky European crowd of late-night smokers. [SEP] Boadas (c/ dels Taller, 1) is a cocktail bar that looks like a movie set for a shoot of 1940s Havana. [SEP] Bar London (c/ Nou de la Rambla, 34) is a rough-and-tumble place with occasional live jazz and rock. [SEP] In a gorgeous medieval palace at c/ Montcada, 20, Espai Barroc is a sumptuous, pricey bar that looks like something out of The Cook, The Thief, His Wife & Her Lover, the Peter Greenaway film. [SEP] Two of the hottest bar scenes are El Born, near Santa María del Mar, and the Port Olímpic near the Hotel Arts. [SEP] You can’t
column3: without tripping into a cocktail. [SEP] A young, hip crowd flocks to chic “design bars” for drinks and dancing. [SEP] Nick Havana (c/ Rosselló, 208) was one of the pioneers of the design bar genre. [SEP] Torres de Ávila, within the Poble Espanyol on Montjuïc, is even more extreme, an adventurous fantasy playground designed by Javier Mariscal, one of the hottest designers of late.

column1: El Molino (Vila i Vila, 99) is one of Barcelona’s oldest cabarets. [SEP] Cabaret of the distinctly kitschy kind is the nightly rule at Bodega Bohemia (Lancaster, 2), on the west side of La Rambla. [SEP] Live jazz most nights of the week can be found at Harlem Jazz Club in the Gothic Quarter (c/ Comtessa de Sobradiel, 8), probably the city’s best jazz club. [SEP] For live flamenco or pop flamenco, head to Los Tarantos, or for jazz, to Jamboree, both on the Plaça Reial. [SEP] Luz de Gas (Muntaner, 246) and Otto Zutz (Lincoln, 15) continue to be the reigning dance clubs, which don’t get going until well after midnight. [SEP] The latest in modern dance, music, and experimental theater is regularly staged in the evenings at the Mercat de les Flors, the old flower market a short
column3: from the spectacular sound-and-light show of the Font Màgica (see page 68). [SEP] If you’re lucky enough to be in the city during a festival—either a religious or secular holiday—you’ll see the city’s different neighborhoods erupt into a carnival. [SEP] Food, fireworks, music, costumes, and especially the huge papier-mâché effigies called gégants (giants) and their comical companions, the cabezudos (bigheads), are essential fiesta features. [SEP] Each neighborhood has its own identifying models. [SEP] The gégants are about 4 meters (13 feet) high and elaborately dressed as kings and queens, knights, ladies, gentlemen, and country folk. [SEP] Cabezudos, meanwhile, are usually oversize cartoon heads of well-known personalities or types. [SEP] They prance about mischievously, accosting people

[SEP] In the wee, wee hours it’s populated by a sometimes motley mix of early-morning newspaper sellers, streetsweepers, and bar hounds stumbling back to their apartments and hotels. [SEP] The broad, tree-shaded, and pedestrian-only promenade stretches nearly 2 km (1 mile) down a gentle incline from the city’s hub, Plaça de Catalunya (see page 54), to the waterfront. [SEP] La Rambla takes its name from an Arabic word meaning a sandy, dry river bed. [SEP] It was a shallow gully until the 14th century, when Barcelona families began to construct homes nearby. [SEP] As the area became more populated, the stream was soon paved over. [SEP] To the north of Las Ramblas (left as you
column3: down it) is the old city, Ciutat Vella; to the south, or right, is El Raval. [SEP] The five sections of La Rambla change in character, as they do in name, as you stroll along. [SEP] The short Rambla de Canaletes at the top is where crowds pour in from the Plaça de Catalunya or emerge from the metro and train stations beneath. [SEP] On Sundays and Mondays in season you’ll find rambunctious knots of fans replaying the games of Barça, the popular name for Barcelona’s beloved football (soccer) club Barcelona F.C.; if an important match has just been won, look out. [SEP] Elderly denizens relax on metal chairs (for which you are supposed to pay) and watch the passing parade. column3: , as the cloister is paved with tombstones, badly worn, but many still bearing the emblems of the bootmakers, tailors, and other craft guilds whose wealth helped pay for the cathedral. [SEP] From the cloister, pass to the Capella de Santa Llúcia, a chapel with 13th- and 14th-century tombstones on the floor and a monument to a crusader knight in armor on one wall. [SEP] Leaving the chapel by its front entrance, turn left at carrer del Bisbe Irurita. column1: Nearby is the Baixada de Santa Eulàlia. [SEP] Just off the street is Plaça de Sant Felip Neri, a tiny and silent square closed to traffic (silent except when the nearby school holds recess here). [SEP] The saint’s church was pockmarked by Italian bombs during the Civil War, though others maintain that firing squads performed executions here. [SEP] The Baixada de Santa Eulàlia descends to carrer dels Banys Nous, named for the long-gone “new” baths of the ghetto erected in the 12th century. [SEP] This winding street, which more or less follows the line of the old Roman wall, is the unofficial boundary of the Barri Gòtic. [SEP] It is also known as the carrer dels antiquaris — the headquarters of antiques dealers. [SEP] As you
column3: along, keep your eyes peeled for unusual hand-painted shop signs, the fretwork of Gothic windows, and dusty treasures in the antiques shop windows. [SEP] You’ll see the old tile signs with a cart symbol high in the walls at some corners, the indication of one-way streets. [SEP] Around the corner is a trio of impossibly pretty plazas. [SEP] Plaça de Sant Josep Oriol adjoins Plaça del Pi, on which sits Santa María del Pi, a handsome church with a tall octagonal bell tower and a harmonious façade pierced by a large 15th-century rose window. [SEP] “Pi” means pine tree, and there is a small specimen here replacing one that was a landmark in past centuries. [SEP] Nevertheless, onward it goes  — when it will be finished, nobody knows. [SEP] For now and perhaps the generation to come, the great spires are marred by ever-present scaffolding and cranes. [SEP] A short
column3: diagonally from La Sagrada Familia is the astonishing Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau, designed by Domènech i Montaner (architect of the Palau de la Música Catalana) and completed by his son. [SEP] The complex of buildings — still a working hospital — is one of modernisme’s most underrated (and least known) achievements. [SEP] Farther north, in a working class neighborhood on the rising slope of the hills behind Gràcia, Parc Guëll, another wildly ambitious Gaudí project, is a residential community completely intertwined with nature. [SEP] Although this project too was never completed according to plan, it is a marvelous place to visit: part park, part Hansel-and-Gretel fantasyland. column1: Waterfront & Barceloneta Barcelona turned its back on the sea in the 19th century and focused on developing industry. [SEP] The sea wall where families loved to
column3: and catch the breeze on stifling summer nights was dismantled. [SEP] Access to and even a view of the sea was obstructed by warehouses and railway tracks. [SEP] Expansion proceeded towards the hills, and La Barceloneta, a neighborhood created in the mid-1700s between the port and the beach, became the district of modest fishermen and sailors. [SEP] Now all this has changed again, and a recreational (and increasingly commercial) area has been newly created along the waterfront. [SEP] Begin a tour of the waterfront at the Columbus Monument, at the foot of the Ramblas. [SEP] To the right is Les Reials Drassanes, begun in 1255, the only medieval shipyard still in existence and now the Museu Marítim (Maritime Museum). [SEP] The 16 bays of these yards, which could once handle more than 30 galleys

[SEP] Tourist interest focuses on the Port Olímpic, the new port, a lively area of restaurants and bars clustered around anchored boats and yachts, the stretch of landscaped beaches called Platjas de Barcelona, and the shopping centered around the deluxe high-rise Hotel Arts, which sits imposingly on the beach. [SEP] You can either take a bus or the metro to La Barceloneta from Plaça de Catalunya. [SEP] A sensational ride back is aboard an aerial cable car ride that traverses the length of the port, providing excellent views of the waterfront and La Rambla. [SEP] The ride climbs to the cable-car tower Torre de Jaume I, 107 meters (351 feet) above the harbor. [SEP] From there you can descend and
column3: back to the Columbus monument area, or continue the aerial lift to Montjuïc at the level of the amusement park. [SEP] Lodged between Port Olímpic and the La Ribera district is Parc de la Ciutadella, the city’s largest park. [SEP] The expanse contains the city zoo (Parc Zoológic and its rare albino gorilla named Snowflake, or Copito de Nieve), the Museu d’Art Modern (Modern Art Museum), the seat of the Parlament de Catalunya, and the foundations of Ciutadella (Citadel). [SEP] It’s a lovely park, with a lake, large old trees, and pleasant pathways. [SEP] The large Baroque fountain, La Cascada, was designed by Josep Fontseré, who had as his assistant a young architecture student named Antoni Gaudí.

[SEP] Photographs show him always neatly dressed and barbered, looking like a Catalan businessman in contrast to the more bohemian Picasso, and in contrast, too, with the surrealist works he created. [SEP] The collection is witty and bright with the bright colors and unique language symbols associated with the artist. [SEP] The Avinguda de Miramar continues past the station of the funicular railway that climbs the hill from the Avinguda del Paral.lel near the Paral.lel metro stop. [SEP] The funicular links up here with a cable car that goes to the Parc d’Atraccions de Montjuïc, an amusement park, and on to the Castell de Montjuïc on the summit. [SEP] Cable cars run daily in summer, weekends-only in winter. [SEP] A short
column3: from the amusement park is the Plaça de l’Armada station for the cable car that crosses the harbor, completing an interesting network of transport by cable. [SEP] The fortress atop Montjuïc, built in 1640, remained in use by the army and then as a prison until shortly before it was turned over to the city to become a museum in 1960. [SEP] The Museu Militar (Military Museum) has an extensive collection of antique weaponry and armor, lead soldiers of different epochs, and models of Catalan castles. [SEP] Here in a basement room you’ll find what may be the only statue of Generalíssimo Francisco Franco to be seen in Barcelona today. [SEP] The Foreign Legation, where foreign governments maintained their own autonomous quarter in Beijing from 1860 to 1937, lies east of Tiananmen Square. [SEP] No longer the location of the diplomatic compounds in the capital, this district still contains many former embassies, clubs, barracks, churches, and commercial buildings, most now converted to Chinese institutes, banks, and offices. [SEP] The architecture is fascinating. column1: The Great Wall is best appreciated at four main sites north of Beijing: Badaling, Mutianyu, Simatai, and Juyongguan. [SEP] Three of these four segments have been carefully refurbished, with the exception of Simatai, which is largely untouched since the days of the early Ming Dynasty. [SEP] The earthen foundations of the wall and watchtowers, as well as much of the brick-work, are original, most of it 300 to 500 years old, although extensive remodeling and fresh materials have been added. [SEP] The look and the feel are authentic enough, once one is on the wall itself, out of sight of the shops, vendors, tour buses, parking lots, and cable cars below. [SEP] The hordes of tourists are another modern addition, of course, but it is possible at all these sites to
column3: beyond the crowds. [SEP] The steep mountain scenery is spectacular and the air is usually quite clear. [SEP] The sheer steepness of the wall’s stone stairs and the precarious footing provided by the irregular treads are what most surprise first-time visitors. [SEP] As it snakes up and down the peaks and ridges, the wall conforms to a challenging topography, one that leaves many tourists gasping for breath. [SEP] But the views from China’s ancient Dragon of Stone make the journey unforgettable. [SEP] The mountain setting is spectacular and the wall rises and falls steeply as it winds up and down the ridges. [SEP] About 7 m (24 ft) high and 5 m (18 ft) wide, this Ming Dynasty fortification is built of tamped earth, stone, and brick. [SEP] Beacon towers of stone and brick are mounted at regular intervals. [SEP] It is possible to
column3: the stairs of the restored section for about 2 km (11⁄2 miles) before reaching the crumbling remains of the original wall on either end. [SEP] At the northern terminus, there is a cable car connecting the wall to a parking lot below. [SEP] The parking lots at the base of the wall are filled with vendors, stores, restaurants, and other modern attractions, including a cinema and a KFC fast-food outlet. [SEP] Badaling is crowded, especially from June through September, but it is quite beautiful. [SEP] Equally attractive is the second-most visited section of the Great Wall at Mutianyu, 88 km (55 miles) northeast of Beijing. [SEP] Mutianyu was opened to tourists in 1986 to relieve the crowding at Badaling. [SEP] There is also a cable car at Mutianyu, eliminating the 20-minute hike up to the wall

column1: The Great Wall at Juyongguan, 58 km (36 miles) northwest of Beijing on the way to the Badaling section, is the newest portion of the wall open to tourism (1998) and the nearest to the capital. [SEP] Juyongguan contains a massive guard tower marking one of the Great Wall’s most celebrated mountain passes. [SEP] This guard tower, built in 1345, is decorated in Buddhist carvings, with inscriptions in Chinese, Tibetan, Sanskrit, and languages of the northern tribes. [SEP] Some of the temples and parks clustered at the pass in the days of the Ming dynasty have also been restored here. [SEP] The wall can be
column3: ed for 4 km (21⁄2 miles) as it winds over the peaks of the Taihang Mountains. [SEP] The least restored, least crowded major segment of the Great Wall near Beijing is at Simatai, 124 km (77 miles) northeast of the capital. [SEP] Not only is Simatai rather far from the capital, it is also quite uncrowded and unreconstructed. [SEP] Its stairways and watchtowers resemble those crumbling edifices one can only glimpse from Badaling, Mutianyu, and Juyongguan. [SEP] The natural scenery is dramatic, and the ruined state of the wall gives Simatai a romantic feel (although there is a cable car to the top). column3: from the Kongreßhalle you’ll find the Reichstag building, its huge, new glass dome, with its mirrored central funnel, visible from much of the city. [SEP] The parliamentary home of Wilhelminian and Weimar Germany displays the proud dedication Dem deutschen Volke (To the German People) on a Neo-Classical façade built in 1894 by Paul Wallot. [SEP] This appeal to patriotism and democracy, set above six Corinthian columns, outlasted the burning in 1933 and the bombs of World War II, and was given renewed significance when Berlin resumed its former role as the seat of government of a unified Germany. [SEP] Today, the dome is a major attraction for Berliners and tourists alike. [SEP] They endure lengthy lines to be able to travel to the top, gazing out at the city and down into the Bundestag cham

column1: On the western edge of Berlin, the dense pine forest which was largely stripped for fuel in 1945, has been replanted, adding to the 18 million pines around 6 million chestnut, linden, beech, birch, and oak trees. [SEP] The lush wooded areas form a reserve for deer, wild boar, marten, foxes, and rabbits, but there are also plenty of green meadows for picnics, and the forest paths are extremely popular with both cyclists and joggers. [SEP] The easiest and most direct way to get to the Grunewald is to take the S-Bahn from Bahnhof Zoo to Grunewald S-Bahn station. [SEP] Alternatively, you could combine your trip with a visit to the museums at Dahlem — the Brücke Museum is only a 20-minute
column3: from the eastern edge of the forest. [SEP] Drivers take the Avus and turn off on the Hüttenweg to Grunewaldsee, a lake offering swimming and sandy beaches. [SEP] On the east shore, in an attractive lakeside setting of beech trees, you will find the Jagdschloß Grunewald, a hunting lodge built in 1542 for Prince Elector Joachim II. [SEP] Situated in a cobbled courtyard, the lodge has been restored to its original Renaissance appearance. [SEP] Inside is displayed a rather curious collection of early German hunting portraits and landscapes, among which can be found some remarkable paintings, in particular a series of panels depicting the Passion Cycle by Lucas Cranach. [SEP] Other German and Dutch works of note are those by Jordaens, Rubens, and Bruyn.

column3: down the path outside the lodge brings you to the rather grand Forsthaus Paulsborn, where you can dine in splendor overlooking the lake. [SEP] On the Grunewald’s west side, along Havelchaussee, the Grunewaldturm (Grunewald Tower) is a Neo-Gothic tower built in 1897 to commemorate the 100th birthday of King Wilhelm I. You can climb the 205 steps to reach the 55-m- (180-ft- ) high observation platform for views as far as Potsdam. [SEP] Ferry stations in the area offer boat rides on the River Havel and forest lakes, and the east bank of the Havel is lined with sandy beaches as far as the Wannsee lakes.

column1: Brücke Museum The Bridge Museum is an intimate, single-story museum situated in a pleasant suburb about 20 minutes’
column3: from Jagdschloß Grunewald. [SEP] Take U1 to Oskar-Helene-Heim, then bus 115 to Pücklerstraße. [SEP] The museum is 5 minutes from the bus stop. [SEP] The museum was created in 1967 to house works of classical modernism, thanks to a legacy of Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, a member of the Expressionist group Die Brücke which worked in Dresden from 1905 to 1913. [SEP] A large number of the group’s works were labeled as “degenerate” and thus destroyed by the Nazis. [SEP] Schmidt-Rottluff’s own bold paintings hang beside the works of fellow Expressionists Emil Nolde, Erich Heckel, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, and Max Pechstein.

[SEP] It was designed by a Mr. Bird, although it also has a resemblance to “Tweetie Bird’s” cage. [SEP] Traffic lights now regulate the junction. [SEP] Remember to look right as you prepare to cross the road! [SEP] On the left as you
column3: up Queen Street is Perot Post Office, named after the man who was appointed Bermuda’s first Postmaster General in 1821. [SEP] He had actually been acting as “unofficial” postman for several years, meeting the ships and putting the letters under his hat before touring the town to deliver them. [SEP] William B. Perot (pronounced “Pea-rut”) went one stage further in 1848 when he began to produce his own postage stamps; only 11 are known to exist today, making each one extremely valuable. [SEP] The little Post Office is very much as Perot kept it, neat and simply furnished. [SEP] The building still houses an active post office, which makes it an appropriate place to buy the stamps for your postcards. column1: Across Victoria Street from the bus terminal is Victoria Park, originally a children’s playground but later landscaped to commemorate the Silver Jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1887. [SEP] The main features are the sunken garden, lawns, and flowerbeds in traditional English style, and the beautiful ornate iron bandstand, where open-air concerts are still performed during the summer and in December just before Christmas. column3: east to the Cathedral of the Most Holy Trinity, consecrated in 1905 after a fire destroyed the previous edifice in 1884. [SEP] The style is Early English, with a tower rising 44 m (143 ft) to provide good views of the town. [SEP] You can climb to the top for a small donation to church funds; the tower is open on weekdays only. [SEP] Perhaps the most dramatic area in the church is the wall behind the altar, where there are sculptures in niches depicting Christ and the saints. [SEP] Completed in 1967 it is a fitting modern edition to the church. [SEP] By contrast, farther along Church Street is the oldest church in Hamilton, St. Andrew’s Presbyterian Church (founded in 1843), as well as Wesley Methodist Church. column1: Outside the Cabinet building on Front Street is the Cenotaph, which commemorates Bermuda’s dead of the two World Wars. [SEP] The monument dates from 1920, its design based on that of the war memorial that stands in London’s Whitehall. [SEP] The solemn ceremonies of Remembrance Day take place here on 11 November each year, when wreaths are laid and silent homage is paid to those who gave their lives. [SEP] From Front Street, a ten-minute
column3: up the steep incline of King Street leads to Fort Hamilton, which was built in 1889 to protect the harbor and formed part of a line of defense for the naval dockyard to the west. [SEP] Today it offers spectacular views over the rooftops of Hamilton, especially thrilling when the cruise ships are in port. [SEP] Don’t worry about trying to take in these views while driving, for there are many stopping places along the way where you can take photographs or simply enjoy the panorama. column1: West End: Somerset and Ireland Islands The bridge that connects Somerset Island and its parish of Sandys (pronounced “Sands”) to the main island is quite short. [SEP] If you travelled on immediately it would be easy to miss one of the curiosities of Bermuda, for Somerset Bridge is said to be the narrowest drawbridge in the world. [SEP] The section which opens is wide enough to allow the passage of only a boat’s mast! [SEP] It is operated by simply lifting two planks of wood by hand; one has to marvel at the skill of the sailors who use the bridge regularly. [SEP] The bridge and surrounding supports were renovated in 1998. [SEP] The ferry service from Hamilton also stops here on its way to Dockyard. [SEP] Take the ferry or
column3: along the old Bermuda Railway Trail, which is extremely scenic along this section. [SEP] There are several deep “cuts” created for the rail line, with tiny wooden foot bridges over the top. [SEP] The road into Somerset Island leads around a pretty bay and onto Fort Scaur, which stands on a rocky hillock hidden from the road. [SEP] The fort was begun in 1869 to protect the land route to the naval dockyard at the end of the island. [SEP] The layout is the so-called Prussian design, a polygon shape developed by German engineers at the time. [SEP] The gunning placements held “disappearing” guns, which could not be seen from land or sea. [SEP] Other gunning placements were also added by US engineers during World War II. column1: Walk through the Cooperage to reach the Victualing Yard, where you will find the Tourist Information Bureau, then across the park and around the dry dock area, which is still used to repair the boats and buoys so vital to ship safety. [SEP] On the left is the Bermuda Pottery, where you’ll find experts crafting and firing ceramics with a series of island motifs. [SEP] Your
column3: will then lead to the Clocktower Building, perhaps the most elegant of the structures at dockyard. [SEP] Its long lines and minimalist façade once housed administrative offices, but the interior has been transformed into a smart shopping mall with luxury goods from jewelry to cigars. [SEP] Above the ground floor shops is a light, open space designed for conventions and exhibitions. [SEP] There are several restaurants in the dockyard as well as places to sit in the sunshine and have a picnic. [SEP] In summer, cruise ships dock at the small port outside the main harbor wall, providing a good picture of how the working dockyard must have looked when it was home to British naval vessels.

column3: ing distance of each other. [SEP] If traveling by bus, get off at the Swizzle Inn, famed across the island for its “Rum Swizzle” drinks (made from a secret recipe); it’s also a great place for lunch. [SEP] Only a short

column3: west from the Inn, you will find the Bermuda Perfumery and Gardens. [SEP] This small family business was established in 1929 by Madeleine and Herbert Scott in a garden shed. [SEP] They moved to their present site in 1939 and proceeded to plant the acres of flowers that serve as raw materials to produce their small range of signature fragrances. [SEP] The business has now been passed on to their son. [SEP] You can take a free tour of the “factory,” housed in a 200-year-old farmhouse, where you can watch the process of perfume production, including the techniques for collecting the ripe blooms. [SEP] Then take your time and wander among the fragrant gardens with their swathes of jasmine, frangipani, and passion flower,their scents heavy in the warm air. column1: he bridge and turn left to get to Ferry Point, an important strategic area of land at the western tip of St. George’s Island. [SEP] There are no less than three separate fortifications here protecting the entrance to St. George’s Harbour. [SEP] The earliest was Burnt Point Fort, built in 1688 to help stop illegal trading by local sailors. [SEP] The Ferry Island Fort, on a small island a short distance offshore, was begun in the 1790s and was almost constantly developed for the next 80 years. [SEP] In 1823, Major Thomas Blanchard constructed Martello Tower on high ground behind the two forts, where soldiers could survey the surrounding land and coastline. [SEP] Today the remains of all three fortifications comprise Ferry Point Park, where it is possible to explore the forts at your leisure,
column3: through woodland, and enjoy the beauties of Lover’s Lake. [SEP] It is a wonderful place to have a picnic, and it’s relatively quiet, even on a summer weekend. [SEP] Returning to Ferry Point junction, take the north fork to St. George’s town. [SEP] You’ll travel around the far side of Mullet Bay — a sheltered natural harbor for small craft — and then past a children’s play area before reaching the outskirts of town. [SEP] (St. George’s can be reached via bus routes [SEP]1, [SEP]3, [SEP]10, and [SEP]11.)

column1: the Bunker Hill Monument commemorates the first battle of the Revolution, on 17 June, 1775 — a hollow victory for the British who suffered more than 1,000 casualties against 400 to 600 for the colonials. [SEP] Despite the name it actually stands on Breed’s Hill, the site of the colonial redoubt in the battle. [SEP] At its base is a swashbuckling statue by William Wetmore Storey of American Colonel Prescott, who gave the famous order: “Don’t fire ’til you see the whites of their eyes.” [SEP] There are informative models depicting the battle’s progress as well as hourly musket-firing demonstrations. [SEP] You can climb the 294 spiral steps to an enclosed deck, which has great views. [SEP] A multimedia presentation at The Bunker Hill Pavilion re-enacts the battle. [SEP] To reach Charlestown:

column1: this was the second busiest port in the United States, with clippers jostling for space. [SEP] Today after a long period of decline, the area has revived and the granite warehouses have been renovated into apartments, restaurants, offices, and hotels. [SEP] The British sailed home from Long Wharf. [SEP] Today you can sail to the Harbor Islands, take a cruise around the harbor, or just sit and admire the craft at anchor. [SEP] On Central Wharf, the New England Aquarium is one of the best anywhere. [SEP] Its centerpiece is a giant 200,000-gallon tank containing a 24-ft- (7-m-) deep coral reef filled with sharks, sea turtles, and 600 fish from 100 species. [SEP] Five times a day, scuba divers go in to feed the fish, a fascinating spectacle to watch. [SEP] Ramps circle the tank so that you can
column3: around the whole thing. [SEP] More than 70 exhibit tanks make up the Aquarium galleries. [SEP] They are categorized as salt or fresh water and feature communities of fish inhabiting different marine climates, from cold and temperate to tropical. [SEP] Visitors can see the life forms found in a salt marsh, a mangrove swamp, or along the New England seashore. [SEP] Kids love the Touch Tide Pool where they can handle crabs and starfish. [SEP] Other perennial favorites are the penguins, the sea otters, and the sea lions, who provide entertainment in the theater. [SEP] The aquarium is currently undergoing an expansion that will triple its size. [SEP] The new West Wing containing a large outdoor seal exhibit, two floors of exhibits, plus visitor facilities opened in 1998. [SEP] A large-format the

column1: There’s an even better view from the top of the 253-ft (77-m) Pilgrim Monument in Provincetown. [SEP] It’s called the Pilgrim monument because this is where the Pilgrims actually landed first before moving on to Plymouth. [SEP] The museum at the base of the tower tells the story. [SEP] P-Town, is a fabled place. [SEP] Although the main street is crowded and lined with commercial tourist trinket stores, it still has a magical atmosphere, because it has an “anything goes” attitude. [SEP] It is the East Coast’s gay mecca (along with the Hamptons, and Cherry Grove and the Pines on Fire Island). [SEP] Same-sex couples
column3: the streets hand in hand, and outrageous transvestites entertain in the cabarets. [SEP] Families come to browse the stores selling T-shirts, and scrimshaw and driftwood curios, and to enjoy the beaches and the fishing and whale-watch trips. [SEP] In the early 20th century Provincetown was a major art colony and there are still numerous art galleries, particularly at the east end of town. [SEP] In summer, the town is swamped and every guesthouse filled. [SEP] In winter, it’s quiet. [SEP] Many of the commercial stores close and only the residents remain — a community of artists, Portuguese fishermen, and a handful of restaurateurs. [SEP] You can visit Provincetown for a day (see page 110), but if you don’t stay longer, you’ll miss half the fun.

column1: The area overlooks the city from a long, narrow plateau, divided into two: the southern part, occupied by the enormous Royal Palace where the original castle once stood, and the northern district of historic streets, where 14th- and 15th-century aristocrats and artisans once rubbed shoulders. [SEP] From Pest there are various ways of getting up to Castle Hill. [SEP] The most popular method of ascent is aboard the 19th-century sikló (funicular) which starts by the end of the Chain Bridge and rises to the Royal Palace. [SEP] Alternatively take the metro to Moszkva tér, climb up the steps to the road, and catch the mini Várbusz service which shuttles to and from Dísz tér, stopping at numerous points en route. [SEP] You could simply
column3: up the hill using any one of several streets and staircases, but one method you cannot use is your own transport; cars are forbidden on the hill (unless you are a resident or a guest at the Hilton Hotel), thus preserving the area’s historic ambience. [SEP] Historic Streets

column1: Historic Streets Turning right at the funicular terminus, a short
column3: brings you to Dísz tér (Parade Square) which marks the start of the northern district. [SEP] The Mátyás templom (Matthias Church) spire, towering gracefully over this historic area, is the best reference point for our tour. [SEP] The church takes its name from Hungary’s favourite medieval king, who married here twice in the 15th century. [SEP] The Emperor Franz Joseph I was crowned king of Hungary here in 1867, to the tune of the Coronation Mass, composed by Liszt for the occasion. [SEP] The original church was built in the mid-13th century, converted into a mosque during the Turkish occupation, and seriously damaged during Buda’s recapture in 1686. [SEP] It was rebuilt in Baroque style after the return of the Christian forces, and between 1873 and 1896 it was completely reconstructed along

column1: At number 9 you can descend deep into the hill via a series of tunnels that were dug in medieval times as an escape route in times of siege. [SEP] They were used again as air-raid shelters and an emergency hospital in 1944–1945. [SEP] Here visitors can join a guided tour of the caves and tunnels, which also contain a waxwork exhibition depicting episodes of Hungarian history. [SEP] Uri utca terminates at Dísz tér, where it’s best to turn and
column3: back along Tárnok utca. [SEP] Among the shops and restaurants here are a number of ﬁne buildings. [SEP] The orange-and-red geometric frescoes painted on the overhanging ﬁrst ﬂoor of the Aranyhordó (Golden Barrel) restaurant are the most noteworthy. [SEP] Next door, number 18 was built as a merchant’s house in the ﬁrst half of the 15th century. [SEP] Used as the Arany Sas (Golden Eagle) pharmacy from 1750 until 1913, it is now the most attractive of this area’s small museums. [SEP] Beautiful old majolica vessels are the stars of an atmospheric re-creation of the pharmacy, and there are also informative displays on potions, practices, and alchemy in the Budapest of this era. [SEP] The ﬁnal street of this district to be explored is the leafy Tóth Arpád sétány. [SEP] This promenade, situated al

column1: dest quarter of Buda, centred on the site of Aquincum, the capital of the Roman province of Lower Pannonia. [SEP] Nowadays it’s a nightmare of Soviet town-planning, with heavy trafﬁc constantly rumbling past on the main northern highway out of Budapest. [SEP] Amid this unlikely setting, however, there are some major Roman remains to be discovered. [SEP] To begin the Roman route, take any number of city buses north to the so-called Military Amphitheatre (Katonai Amﬁteátrum), thus distinguishing it from a smaller one a short distance farther north. [SEP] Gladiators performed here in the second century to amuse legionnaires. [SEP] Completely forgotten for centuries, the ruins were only partially restored in the 1930s. [SEP] Now it’s effectively a grassy piece of parkland where locals play and
column3: their dogs, but enough remains of the amphitheatre walls and outline to give a good idea of what it was once like. [SEP] Farther north, beneath the Flórián tér ﬂyover on the Buda side of the Arpád Bridge, stand the ruins of baths built for the Roman legions. [SEP] Take the

column1: Buda Hills The Buda Hills area is a greenbelt that lies due west of Rózsadomb, though it stretches as far north as Obuda and as far south as the start of the M7 highway. [SEP] Choose a clear day, then catch any one of several trams or buses which go past the cog-railway terminus (just west of Moszkva tér, opposite the Hotel Budapest). [SEP] There is room on the train for mountain bikes if you are feeling particularly active. [SEP] The train passes smart residential houses on its way to the terminus and park of Sváb-hegy. [SEP] A short
column3: across the park (just follow the crowds) is the stop for the Children’s Railway (Széchenyi-hegyi Gyermekvasút), thus named because it is operated almost entirely by school-children; only the engine drivers are adults. column1: Just off here is Szervita tér, notable for a splendid patriotic-religious Art Nouveau mosaic fantasy. [SEP] It occupies the very top of the old Turkish Banking House. [SEP] Head south along Petoﬁ Sándor utca; on your right is the Párisi Udvar (Paris Arcade), built in 1909. [SEP] Inside, look up to enjoy the exotic Art Nouveau styling and glasswork; then
column3: round to see the stylish front of the building, where there is an IBUSZ tourist information ofﬁce. [SEP] Directly across the busy road (it’s best to use the underpass) are three ﬁne churches and part of the university complex. [SEP] On the corner of Ferenciek tere stands the Franciscan Church, constructed around 1758. [SEP] Look at the relief on the side wall, depicting the ﬂood of 1838 that caused massive destruction in the entire inner city. [SEP] Then continue along Károlyi Mihály utca, past the yellow University Library building on your left. [SEP] On the opposite corner is the University Church (Egyetemi templom). [SEP] Built between 1725 and 1742 by the monks of the Order of St. Paul, it features splendidly rich Baroque carving. [SEP] Turn into Szerb utca, where there are more univers

column1: Lipótváros Bounded by Jozséf Attila utca to the south and by Bajcsy-Zsilinszky út to the east, Lipótváros (Leopold Town) lies directly north of the inner city. [SEP] Directions to find the Basilica of St. Stephen (Szent István Bazilika) aren’t needed, as its 96-metre (315-foot) dome dominates the skyline. [SEP] The biggest church in Budapest, built between 1851 and 1905, it is frequently full to its capacity of 8,500 people. [SEP] Its exterior is in a poor state, though slowly being restored. [SEP] Before seeing the interior, ascend the tower. [SEP] It’s a long
column3: to the top, but you are rewarded with Pest’s highest viewpoint. [SEP] The interior of the basilica is dimly lit. [SEP] There is an interesting main attraction in a reliquary in a rear chapel: the Szent Jobb (“Holy Right”) is the much revered holy relic of the right hand of St. Stephen; you’ll need a 20-forint piece to illuminate it.

column3: to the north, is probably Pest’s ﬁnest architectural ensemble. [SEP] At its centre is an obelisk dedicated to the Soviet troops who fell in the city, but the enormous, ostentatious buildings surrounding the square are what really steal the show. [SEP] The superb lemon-coloured Art Nouveau building close to the obelisk is home to the American Embassy. [SEP] Next door is the former Stock Exchange (now the country’s TV headquarters), a showy, eclectic building with some good reliefs. [SEP] The Hungarian National Bank on the opposite side of the square is the work of the same architect. [SEP] The great dome of Parliament, equal in height to that of the basilica, is clearly visible from the square. column1: San Franciscans are quite unashamedly in love with their town. [SEP] Its natural setting, nestled in the hills around the bay, makes the city uncommonly cozy; the zip in the air is invigorating, and even the fog that rolls in off the ocean seems more romantic than chilling. [SEP] If you have a car, one way to begin your visit is to travel along 49-Mile Drive, which provides a comprehensive tour of the main sights. [SEP] You’ll need to use a good map, as the blue signposts with a white seagull in the center can be difficult to locate. [SEP] Stop off at Twin Peaks (the road to get there starts near the southern end of Market Street) for an excellent panoramic view of the city and the bay, then park the car, put on a pair of comfortable
column3: ing shoes, and take to the city’s first-class public transport system (see page 120). [SEP] Start at the bridge. [SEP] The city has more than one, but the one is, of course, the Golden Gate Bridge. [SEP] The name Golden Gate was given to the city’s harbor entrance in 1846 by Captain John Frémont, but the mile-wide channel lay unspanned until the bridge, a masterpiece of engineering by Joseph Strauss, was completed in 1937. [SEP] At 4,200 ft (1,280 m), it was the world’s longest single span until New York’s Verrazano Narrows Bridge surpassed it in 1964, but few would deny that it remains the most beautiful suspension bridge in the world. [SEP] It took four years and $35 million to build; more than 40 million vehicles now cross over the span every year. [SEP] You can take a bus to the bridge

column1: At the Broadway Street edge of the Gaslamp Quarter, you can’t miss Horton Plaza, one of the best modern shopping malls in the United States. [SEP] Along with six floors of shops and restaurants, open-air terraces, and quirky decorations, visitors will find the local half-price ticket booth, Times Arts Tix (Tel. 619/497-5000). [SEP] Broadway ends at the harbor, where visitors can visit one of several 19th-century ships moored on the Embarcadero and belonging to the excellent Maritime Museum. [SEP] The city’s pride and joy is the iron-hulled square-rigger Star of India, built in the Isle of Man in 1863. [SEP] The Star is the oldest sailing ship that is still seaworthy; she makes a celebratory cruise twice each summer. [SEP] A brief
column3: along the waterfront leads to Seaport Village, a lively complex of shops, restaurants, and galleries overlooking the harbor. [SEP] One of the best ways to appreciate San Diego’s sparkling beauty is from the sea. [SEP] You can take a cruise along the bay — boat trips leave from Harbor Drive, just south of the Maritime Museum — out past the man-made Harbor and Shelter Islands and around the tip of the Coronado peninsula (occupied by a US Naval Air Station — the film Top Gun was set nearby in northern San Diego) to Point Loma out on the Pacific coast. [SEP] The seemingly endless procession of fishing boats, yachts, and US Navy vessels makes for a fascinating tour.

column1: The oldest part of San Diego is situated 3 miles (4.8 km) north of downtown in the area known as Old Town (bounded by Juan, Congress, Twiggs, and Wallace streets). [SEP] Here, in 1769, the European colonization of California commenced, beginning with the construction of Father Junípero Serra’s Mission San Diego de Alcala. [SEP] In this area of restored adobe buildings, you can enjoy a rest under the palms and eucalyptus of Plaza Vieja (originally the town plaza and bullfight arena before the Yankees arrived), browse among the stalls selling Mexican handicrafts, or eat at one of the many restaurants. [SEP] Cabrillo National Monument, situated on the Point Loma promontory (I-5/I-8 exit on Rosecrans Street and follow the signs), celebrates the man who discovered San Diego Bay. [SEP] You can
column3: the trails around the point, visit the Old Point Loma Lighthouse, and at low tide explore the tide pools for crabs, starfish, anemone, and, if you are lucky, perhaps even the odd, elusive octopus. [SEP] If you’re here between December and March, watch for migrating gray whales from the look-out point near the lighthouse. [SEP] Other aquatic pursuits can be enjoyed at Mission Bay, a first-class watersports center and park. [SEP] The bay is also home of the famous Sea World marine park, where you’ll be able to watch performing two-ton killer whales. [SEP] Children especially will enjoy the antics of the trained dolphins, sea lions, and otters.

[SEP] The real back country is found 11 miles (18 km) along the High Sierra Trail, beyond Crescent Meadow at Bearpaw Meadow. [SEP] The hike is not too formidable, and the meadow has a rudimentary campsite — though spaces are limited. [SEP] Within a day’s

column1: Get up at dawn — you won’t regret it — and drive out to Zabriskie Point. [SEP] As the sun rises behind you, the light hits Tucki Mountain and the tips of the Panamints to the west before plunging into the valley’s primeval salt lake far below. [SEP] Continue to Dante’s View (altitude 5,745 ft/1,750 m), where you can look out westward to Wildrose, Bennett, and Telescope peaks. [SEP] Down in the valley in front of you lies the salty puddle called Badwater — at 282 ft (86 m) below sea level, which is the lowest point in the western hemisphere. [SEP] The crazed and pinnacled surface of the salt-caked lake bed has earned it the nickname of Devil’s Golf Course. [SEP] Take a
column3: out across that glaring expanse of baked salt — the atmosphere of desolation is almost exhilarating. [SEP] If you look closer at the salt under your feet, you’ll discover that the expansion of the crystallizing mineral has heaved it into bizarre funnels, swirls, and other intricate patterns. [SEP] On the way back toward Furnace Creek lies Artist’s Drive, where the road (one way only from south to north) carves its path through a canyon of multi-colored rocks, culminating in the very aptly named Artist’s Palette. [SEP] Here, oxidization has turned the rocks bright mauve, ochre, green, vermilion, turquoise, and purple.

column1: he elegant shopping thoroughfare, Bloor Street, is the fashionable hub of the city. [SEP] Following John Simcoe’s military grid pattern, Toronto’s main arteries run from the lakefront north: Spadina and University Avenues, Bay, Yonge, and Church Streets; and east–west: Front, King, Queen, Dundas, College-Carlton, and Bloor Streets. [SEP] Our sightseeing itinerary starts down at the waterfront and works north through the business district to the chic shopping and museum area. [SEP] As an alternative, especially if you have children, you may prefer to start downtown, around Union Station, and visit the other sights to the north before coming back to relax among the recreational attractions of the waterfront. [SEP] Getting around the city is quite simple, but while downtown, park your car and
column3: or use the buses or subway. [SEP] Waterfront Area

[SEP] In a transformation no less dramatic than the Harbourfront, the hippy slum of the 1960s has been refurbished into a chic neighborhood of fashionable boutiques, art galleries, side
column3: cafés, gourmet restaurants, and colorfully repainted old houses. [SEP] Hazelton Lanes is a delightful variation on the conventional shopping mall, where the maze of

column1: Accommodatingly situated on the border between Ontario and Québec, Ottawa is a fully bilingual city, though most of the French-speaking community (and the best restaurants) now have their homes in Hull on the Québec side of the Ottawa River. [SEP] Except for longer excursions, try to leave the car in the hotel parking lot and
column3: or take the bus. [SEP] The complex system of one-way streets designed to avoid rather than to reach key government buildings, and the added confusion of curving rivers and canals, make downtown driving a harrowing business even for locals. [SEP] One other point: In the absence of any clear logic in street numbering, it’s important when noting an address to be sure you have the nearest cross-streets as well as the number of the building. [SEP] Parliament Area

column1: Where the road crosses over the Rideau River and Green Island, look for Rideau Falls, pouring its double “curtain” (French rideau) of water into the Ottawa River. [SEP] The windmill is part of a Renewable Energy Exhibit of methods of gathering solar and wind energy. [SEP] For Canadians, 24 Sussex Drive has the same significance as 10 Downing Street for the British. [SEP] This grey stone house hidden behind the greenery is the Canadian Prime Minister’s residence. [SEP] His neighborhood, in Rideau Hall just along the road (1 Sussex Drive), is the official residence of the monarchy, the governor general. [SEP] Except on official occasions, the guards in appropriately British uniforms will usually let you drive or
column3: in to admire the sweeping stretch of lawns and gardens — look for the governor’s toboggan slide and skating rink. [SEP] The drive then circles around the immaculate gardens and fine mansions of Rockcliffe Park. [SEP] The park’s driveway takes you out to the Rockcliffe Lookout for a spectacular view of the Ottawa River and the mouth of the Gatineau. [SEP] In the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Barracks, at the north end of St. Laurent Boulevard, you can see some of the horses performing or training for the popular RCMP Musical Ride, the one occasion when the Mounties are still Mounties.

column1: Mount Royal For an overall view of the city, start with a bracing
column3: up the slopes of the charming Mount Royal Park (Parc du Mont-Royal). [SEP] Follow the footpath and stairs from the end of Peel Street or a shorter route from the Chemin Remembrance car park. [SEP] Perhaps the most pleasant way is to take a leisurely ride in a horse-drawn carriage from Dominion Square. [SEP] Known with characteristic local irony as la Montagne (the Mountain), the heights were spotted by Jacques Cartier on his historic journey up the St. Lawrence River in 1535, and named Mont Réal in homage to his king François I.

[SEP] In the 19th century, Notre-Dame-de-Bonsecours became the “Sailors’ Chapel,” to which survivors of shipwrecks brought model ships they had carved as offerings of thanksgiving. [SEP] The models still hang from the ceiling, lit up now by tiny electric bulbs. [SEP] Notice how the trompe l’oeil painting on the low arched ceiling aspires to turn the little church into a lofty Gothic cathedral. [SEP] Climb the church tower for a good view of Vieux Montréal and the harbor. [SEP] Most of the ugly old warehouses have been demolished along the Vieux Port at the foot of Place Jacques-Cartier. [SEP] Some have been refurbished as cafés or hotels; one pier now houses the headquarters for the Cirque du Soleil, another an IMAX theater. [SEP] Take a
column3: along the port to Pointe à Callières, where the Ville-Marie settlers first landed. [SEP] An obelisk on the nearby Place Royale commemorates their adventure. [SEP] The statue at the Pointe is of an Anglo-Canadian, John Young, who developed the port’s commerce in the 19th century. [SEP] The rue St-Sulpice takes you over the Place d’Armes, close to the site of the first French battles with the Iroquois. [SEP] Today it serves as a visual link between the historic old town of the pioneers and the new city of commerce and industry. [SEP] In the middle is a statue of Maisonneuve, looking very like one of Alexandre Dumas’ musketeers. [SEP] He’s brandishing the royal French fleur-de-lys flag that inspired the Québec provincial flag of today. [SEP] The 19th-century Neo-Gothic Notre-Dame Basilica was

[SEP] It is named after Count Louis de Frontenac, a rascally 17th-century French governor who upset the clergy by encouraging the sale of brandy to the native peoples. [SEP] Take a look inside at the stucco carvings, tapestries, and handsome wood paneling. [SEP] Behind the hotel, beyond an 1898 statue of Samuel de Champlain, the city’s founder, Dufferin Terrace offers a magnificent view over the St. Lawrence and downriver to the Ile d’Orléans. [SEP] Stroll alongside a pleasant little garden, Parc des Gouverneurs, with its obelisk paying tribute to Generals Wolfe and Montcalm, both killed at the great battle for Québec in 1759. [SEP] The terrace is prolonged by the Promenade des Gouverneurs, continuing the
column3: along the foot of the citadel towards Battlefields Park. [SEP] North of the Frontenac, Place d’Armes is the center of Old Québec, where troops were mustered and paraded, proclamations read out, criminals whipped or executed. [SEP] In the middle, the Monument of Faith (Monument de la Foi) commemorates the work of French Catholic missionaries in North America. [SEP] On the north side of the square, the Musée du Fort, 10 rue Ste-Anne, stages a sound and light show alternately in English and French on the military history of Québec City.

column1: Down on the harborfront today, the old wharves, warehouses, even the houses of joyous ill-repute that cluster in back streets around any international port have been refurbished as Historic Properties, a bright and breezy neighborhood of artists’ studios and galleries, shops, restaurants, and taverns with open-air terraces. [SEP] The board
column3: takes you through a colorful architecture of red brick, timber, grey stone, and gaily painted clapboard. [SEP] Summer attractions include a puppet theater, concerts, lobster races, and windsurfing competitions. [SEP] At the international tournament of town criers, hear local newsmongers in 18th-century costume pitting their Oyez! against the best bellowers from Britain and Bermuda. [SEP] Anchored by Privateers’ Warehouse (Halifax was a popular haven for pirates from the Napoleonic Wars to the rum-running Prohibition Era of the 1920s) is a grand racing schooner, Bluenose II. [SEP] The men may be laying out dozens of cod to dry on what are known as flakes, the same trestled wooden racks still used in fishing villages all down the coast. [SEP] At the drawbridge to Porte Dauphine, the main entrance gate bearing a relief of three fleurs-de-lys, the French royal coat of arms, you’ll be stopped by French soldiers to check whether you’re a British spy. [SEP] Continue over to the King’s Bastion, the military barracks where living conditions show the kind of stark contrast that nurtured enough discontent to cause a mutiny in that year of 1744. [SEP] The gabled Governor’s Wing numbers ten luxurious apartments with fine furniture, tapestries, silks, brocades, silverware, and delicate porcelain. [SEP] Watch the Reversing Falls Rapids from the bridge on Highway 100. [SEP] The tourist information office there will tell you the best times to watch the tides’ evolution. [SEP] At low tide, the Fundy’s waters are 4 m (13 ft) lower than the Saint John River, causing it to cascade through a narrow gorge into the bay. [SEP] Gradually the flow slows down as the tide begins to rise again. [SEP] At the tide’s turn, the slack enables ships to pass the rapids before the flow builds up in the opposite direction. [SEP] The bay’s high tide of more than 4 m (13 ft) above the river thrusts all the way inland to Fredericton, 130 km (78 miles) away. [SEP] On your riverside

column1: Bay of Fundy Take Highway 1 northeast from Saint John and turn off at Penobsquis to head for Fundy National Park, a wonderful nature reserve with an emphasis on the seashore and its spectacular high tides. [SEP] At the park entrance, you can get detailed maps of the 110 km (68 miles) of hiking and biking trails linking campgrounds and chalets inside the park. [SEP] An arts-and-crafts school offers courses in wood-carving and copper jewelry for adults, and basket-weaving and glass-painting for children. [SEP] On Bennett Lake, you can rent a canoe or fish from a rowboat. [SEP] On the shore,
column3: along the flats at low tide to seek out periwinkles, barnacles, and sea anemones underneath the rocks. [SEP] Herring Cove gives you a good view and detailed explanations of the tides. [SEP] Take a side-trip to Hopewell Cape at the mouth of the Petit-codiac River. [SEP] If you can, camp overnight, as dawn is the perfect time to enjoy the view of its red cliffs and bizarre pillars of granite topped with tufts of balsam fir and black spruce, revealed at low tide. [SEP] The rocks have been buffeted into what the tourist office calls the Grant Flowerpots.
