[SEP] The harbor separates the city proper, with the Stanley Park promontory, from its elegant north shore mountainside suburbs of West and North Vancouver. [SEP] To take in all this, you need to begin from not one, but two observation points. [SEP] Cross the First Narrows on Lions Gate Bridge and take the Capilano Road for a cable-car ride, “Skyride,” up to Grouse Mountain and its grand view south over the city and harbor. [SEP] Try to be there at sunset, too, to see the city light up. [SEP] A favorite with skiers, the mountain also offers a fine view northwest over Capilano Lake and across to Vancouver Island. [SEP] If you feel like a quick whiff of the wilderness on your way back, turn off to
column3: the swaying suspension bridge 76 m (230 ft) above the fast-flowing waters of Capilano Canyon. [SEP] To get an equally impressive view of the city set against its mountains, go downtown to the observation deck (and its restaurant, if you like) on top of the 40-story Harbour Centre (555 West Hastings Street). [SEP] A bonus on clear days is a view south, with the long-range telescope, of Mount Baker across the American border in the state of Washington.

column1: Turning west, you’ll pass on the seaward side a bronze statue oddly named Girl in a Wet Suit, a version of Copenhagen’s mermaid designed not to shock. [SEP] Stop off at Prospect Point for a good view of oil tankers and grain cargo ships bound for Japan, China, or Russia. [SEP] A totem pole marks the site where Captain Vancouver met with members of the Squamish tribe. [SEP] At the Aquarium the star attractions are the dolphin show and the beluga whales, closely followed by polar bears. [SEP] Equally fantastic are wolf-eels with crab-cracking jaws. [SEP] Bears and monkeys seem to be having much less fun at the nearby zoo. [SEP] You can
column3: marked trails to picnic at the pretty freshwater Beaver Lake, from which the beavers were “deported” after creating havoc with the water system. [SEP] The park’s popular sandy beaches run along the west shore of the peninsula. [SEP] English Bay

column1: Route 99 turns north at Horseshoe Bay (landing area for the Vancouver Island ferry) to become the Squamish Highway for a spectacular 100-km (60-mile) drive up to Whistler Mountain. [SEP] The Coastal Mountains come right down to the water’s edge of the narrow Howe Sound, some forming a little archipelago in the sea. [SEP] Stop off at Shannon Falls, a short
column3: away from the road on an easy gravel path over footbridges into the forest. [SEP] You can picnic at the bottom of the cliff over which the water cascades. [SEP] Famous for its August log-rolling contests, the town of Squamish makes a useful base for hiking tours into Garibaldi Provincial Park. [SEP] The winter sports resort of Whistler offers excellent summer facilities, too: bicycles, kayak and river-rafting or more sedate swimming, golf, and tennis. [SEP] Take the ski-lift for views across the Coastal Mountains or stroll around Lost Lake — good trout-fishing — but beware of a pretty yellow flower known as skunk cabbage that smells like its name when you pick it. [SEP] As a delightful alternative to driving, you can travel from Vancouver to Squamish aboard the Royal Hudson 2860 steam train

column1: Coming from Vancouver, board the car ferry at Horseshoe Bay for Nanaimo and head north on Highway 19. [SEP] Turn west at Parksville to cross the island on Highway 4. [SEP] This takes you through some of the province’s finest forestland: the red cedar of canoes, totem poles and longhouses; stately Douglas fir, mainstay of white man’s bridges, boats, houses, and flagstaffs; and the good old Sitka spruce Christmas tree. [SEP] About 20 km (12 miles) from Parksville, look for a signpost to Little Qualicum Falls. [SEP] The well-marked
column3: loops around the upper falls tumbling into a ravine, then follows the river rapids along to the lower falls that crash into another rocky gorge. [SEP] You can extend the hike along the river for a picnic or bracing swim at Cameron Lake. [SEP] Highway 4 follows the lake shore to Cathedral Grove, a formidable stand of Douglas firs in MacMillan Provincial Park, donated to the public by a paper manufacturer as a gesture for government permission to exploit less accessible parts of the forest. [SEP] Many of the firs, up to 76 m (230 ft) high, are more than 300 years old, the most ancient dating back to the 12th century. [SEP] Excellent explanatory panels trace the growth of these majestic trees. [SEP] Off the beaten track, you’ll steep yourself in the atmosphere of a truly primeval forest.

[SEP] With only one secluded hotel on its shores, the pearshaped lake’s tranquillity is less troubled by noisy tour groups than some of the more popular Rocky Mountain resorts. [SEP] The lake path makes a delightful two-hour ramble through woodland, giving you a good chance of spotting some of the park’s small wildlife, notably some very chubby brown porcupine and an occasional beaver. [SEP] Back on the Trans-Canada, the turn-off 6 km (31/2 miles) after Field takes you past the park information center to a steep winding route through the pine forests of the Yoho Valley. [SEP] Signposted on the right, 13 km (8 miles) into the valley is a short
column3: to the foot of the spectacular Takakkaw Falls. [SEP] Takakkaw is an Indian word for “magnificent,” a fair description of the waters spilling out of the outflow of the Daly Glacier. [SEP] Unlike many waterfalls, this one is at its most spectacular on the hottest summer afternoons, when the glacier ice melts. [SEP] For a panoramic view of the glacier, take the Highline Trail 1 km (1/2 mile) south of the falls, starting out from the Whiskey Jack Hostel. [SEP] On the way back, stop south of the confluence of the Yoho and Kicking Horse rivers for a view of the Spiral Tunnels. [SEP] Watch trains entering and reappearing from the upper of two tunnels bored into the mountain to form a figure 8. [SEP] The lower spiral is visible from the Trans-Canada Highway. [SEP] Stop first at the Crowfoot Glacier, where you can see the foot’s two remaining “toes,” the third having broken away. [SEP] The mass of ice facing you is 55 m (165 ft) thick. [SEP] At Bow Summit, leave the Parkway at the signpost to the viewpoint overlooking the lovely Peyto Lake, a deep turquoise at the height of summer. [SEP] If you have time, stop at Kilometer 119 on the Parkway, to hike up the winding path to Parker’s Ridge (2,185 m/6,560 ft) above pretty alpine meadows overlooking the Saskatchewan Glacier, the beginning of the great North Saskatchewan River that ends up in Hudson Bay. [SEP] Inside Jasper National Park, put on good rubber or crepesoled shoes to

[SEP] Note the rock debris or rubble (moraine in the language of glaciologists) in front of the glacier showing that the Athabasca is retreating — a hundred years ago it reached to the other side of the Parkway. [SEP] At the Parkway’s Kilometer 200 mark, take Highway 93A to Athabasca Falls. [SEP] A comfortable board

[SEP] This is just one of the town’s many modern skyscrapers clustered around the commercial hub of Portage and Main, which has the reputation of being the windiest spot in Canada. [SEP] In the splendid Manitoba Museum of Man and Nature (190 Rupert Avenue), prehistoric and present-day animals are presented in beautifully recreated environments of Arctic wastelands, tundra, woodland, and waterfalls, complete with bird sounds, eerie wolf howls, or the terrifying roar of a forest fire. [SEP] The province’s ethnic groups are shown in traditional costume and old homesteads; special emphasis is given to Manitoba’s Indians and a Métis buffalo hunt. [SEP] Be sure to
column3: around the reconstructed decks of the 17th-century Nonsuch ketch that pioneered Hudson Bay’s involvement in the fur trade. [SEP] The museum adjoins the Centennial Center, home of the Winnipeg Symphony Orchestra, Manitoba Opera Association and Royal Winnipeg Ballet. [SEP] If you’re not around for the ballet performances there from October to May, look out for the summer Ballet in the Park shows in Assiniboine Park, west of town off the Trans-Canada Highway.

column1: Bustling Las Palmas, (population 450,000 — the largest city in the Canaries and the seventh largest in Spain), is a major commercial and historical center, a cosmopolitan resort, and a vital seaport all rolled into one. [SEP] It is one of the busiest ports in the world. [SEP] The real hub of Las Palmas is the Parque de Santa Catalina. [SEP] This square is effectively one gigantic outdoor café that buzzes day and night, and is just a short
column3: to Playa de las Canteras. [SEP] This superb golden beach stretches for 3 to 5 km (2 to 3 miles) and a natural reef just offshore means that the water couldn’t be calmer. [SEP] Las Canteras and the area behind it reflect the city’s cosmopolitan nature. [SEP] Like the city in general, it has seen better days and is losing younger tourist trade to the smarter modern resorts in the south. [SEP] Away from Las Canteras make your first stop Doramas Parque, a pleasantly landscaped park named after a Guanche island chieftain, and adjacent to the park is the Pueblo Canario (Canary Village). [SEP] This is a romanticized version of a Canarian village where you can shop for handicrafts and watch displays of folk dancing and singing. [SEP] The 16th-century Castillo de San Gabriel, situated close to the center of town, houses a small museum of no great standing. [SEP] But it is worth the
column3: across the small drawbridge and over the lagoon, onto the small island that the castle used to deter pirates. [SEP] The Castillo de San José, a few kilometers, to the north, is a far more interesting proposition. [SEP] Built in the 18th century, this well-preserved fortress that once guarded the harbor it overlooks, now houses the late César Manrique’s small but impressive International Museum of Contemporary Art. [SEP] This includes works by Picasso and Miró, and is also notable for the contrast between the modern exhibits and the ancient structure that houses them. [SEP] The island’s major resort is Puerto del Carmen and its long golden beach stretches for about 5 km (3 miles) and comfortably accommodates its visitors. [SEP] Between the island and the mainland is Laguna Nichupté, a huge seawater lagoon bounded by mangrove swamps that are havens to numerous species of wildlife. [SEP] Today a string of hotels have taken much of the beachfront real estate; the balance given over to bars, nightclubs, and shopping malls. [SEP] On the lagoon side, watersports and eco-tours abound in the calmer shallow waters. [SEP] Blue signs denote public beach access and there are no restrictions, so you can

[SEP] Finding your way around the resort couldn’t be simpler. [SEP] The addresses of most hotels or restaurants will include their position on Kukulkán Boulevard in kilometers; the farther south, the bigger the number. [SEP] This guide explores the island from north to south, giving the exact location of attractions in kilometers to make it easy for you to find what you need. [SEP] The island has many loyal fans that return year after year for its particular atmosphere. [SEP] Six km (4 miles) from Playa Morena is the entrance to the San Gervasio Archaeological Park. [SEP] The remains of San Gervasio are located several kilometers from the site entrance, and though not on the scale of the major Mayan settlements of the mainland, the beautiful tropical park environment makes the ruins worth exploring. [SEP] Most structures date from the post-classical period (1200–1650); the site was still in use when the Spanish arrived. [SEP] At the Estructura Manitas (Little Hands Structure), you can clearly see the red handprints, dating from around 1000, on the inside wall of the temple. [SEP] From here you can

[SEP] Some 500 m (1,524 ft) behind here is Kana Nah (Tall House), which, as its name suggests, is one of the largest structures at the site. [SEP] It was the main temple, where the goddess Ix chel was worshipped. [SEP] South to Tulum along theMaya Riviera

[SEP] Cobá more than any other site requires sensible footwear, hat, sunscreen, and bottled water, because the principal structures are spread so widely apart. [SEP] The main building at the site is the Iglesia or church, a huge pyramid nearly 30 m (90 ft) high. [SEP] It sits among a number of structures known as the Grupo Cobá, which lie to the right of the main entrance. [SEP] Its major staircase has been cleared, and the view from the top is spectacular, with the lakes and jungle stretching out to cover the land. [SEP] At irregular intervals, vegetation-covered mounds indicate other pyramids yet to be freed. [SEP] The only other large structure in view is the stone façade of Nohoch Mul (Big Hill) some 20 minutes’
column3: away. [SEP] At 42 m (138 ft), Nohoch Mul is the largest Mayan pyramid yet discovered; there are 120 steps to its upper platform. [SEP] Once there you will find images of the Descending God — the same image seen so often at Tulum. [SEP] Between the Nohoch Mul group and Grupo Cobá is Conjunto de las Pinturas (Paintings Group) where you can see the Pyramid of the Painted Lintel, which as the name suggests still bears traces of its original coloring. column1: The Forbidden City, so described because it was off-limits to ordinary people for nearly 500 years, is now called the Palace Museum. [SEP] Designed to contain the auspicious number of 9,999 rooms, its scale is overwhelming and leaves many visitors bewildered. [SEP] Built in the years 1406–1420, it was the residence of 24 emperors for nearly seven centuries. [SEP] Tourists normally enter the Forbidden City from the south, after a long
column3: along a cobbled roadway from the Gate of Heavenly Peace. [SEP] The main entrance to the compound, Meridian Gate (Wumen), was designed in the 15th century. [SEP] Officials used the left portal, members of the imperial family the right. [SEP] Next comes another ceremonial gate, the Gate of Supreme Harmony (Taihemen), first erected in 1420. [SEP] A pair of monumental bronze lions stand guard. [SEP] Beyond this powerful defense line stands China’s supreme ensemble of ancient architecture. [SEP] First and foremost is the Hall of Great Harmony (Taihedian), popularly called the “Hall of the Imperial Throne.” [SEP] This is the biggest building in the Forbidden City and one of China’s most beautiful wooden structures. column1: The first elements of the wall system were built more than 2,000 years ago, but the expansion and consolidation of the project near Beijing began under the Ming Dynasty in the 14th century. [SEP] The serpentine stone bulwark and elevated highway became Wanlichangcheng — “The Wall Ten Thousand Li Long” (about 6,000 km/3,700 miles). [SEP] The restored section of the wall at Badaling, undulating up the unexpectedly steep hillsides, can be a test of a tourist’s endurance. [SEP] It is far steeper and more formidable than it looks in any tourist brochure. [SEP] Out of breath, many visitors exchange sympathetic smiles along the way as they ascend to one or another of the towers. [SEP] If you
column3: far enough west, you come upon unrestored sections of the wall at the edge of the Gobi Desert. [SEP] The Badaling section is often overcrowded these days. [SEP] Two other sections now provide relatively easy access to tourists: the Great Wall at Mutianyu, as beautiful as the section at Badaling but a little less steep, and the Great Wall at Simatai, more distant from Beijing than other sections but virtually unrestored. [SEP] Simatai is the least crowded and most original of the Great Wall sites. [SEP] Although it too has a cable-car concession, Simatai bills itself as “the most dangerous section of the Great Wall.”

column1: The sightseeing you remember best might be the lively free market lining the hundreds of steps that descend higgledy-piggledy from the hills of central Chongqing to the river. [SEP] Hustling, bustling peasants hawk the rich harvest of the surrounding farming country: cabbages and oranges, eggs and live chickens (they are weighed while flapping), river fish and squirming eels, and table after table of the most fragrant spices, while stalls and hole-in-the-wall cafés heat up the city’s number-one dish, the Sichuan hotpot. [SEP] Sights worth seeing in town include the Chongqing People’s Hall, built in 1953 to serve as a 4,000-seat conference hall and hotel. [SEP] It blends the styles of the Ming and Qing dynasties with the needs of a modern conference hall. [SEP] The Chongqing Museum, while poorly-lit and aging, does contain a collection of dinosaur eggs and two 3,000-year-old wooden boats that, suspended from the cliffs of the Yangzi, served as caskets for nobles in the days of the Ba Kingdom. column1: The café life in Dali is one of its chief delights. [SEP] Cafés are perfect spots to wile away the sunny hours over coffee or beer or to meet local Bai people as well as other travelers. [SEP] Perhaps the most famous of the dozens of cafés is Mr. China Son’s Cultural Exchange Café, run by Uncle Li (Heliyi), the first Bai in history to go abroad. [SEP] His autobiography, on sale at his café, is an epic soap opera. [SEP] Dali also has sights and attractions well worth attending to when the café and bistro scene begins to pale. [SEP] Erhai Lake is a 30-minute
column3: from town, and its main village, Caicun, is a maze of unpaved alleys and mud houses. [SEP] Ferries cross the lake to even more remote villages, including the temple dedicated to Guanyin (goddess of mercy) on Putuo Island. [SEP] Any of dozens of local travel agents can quickly arrange an excursion to lakeside villages, including the market at Wase. [SEP] One popular diversion is the Monday morning outdoor market at Shaping, 30 minutes up the eucalyptus-lined road by minibus from Dali. [SEP] It’s a vast market of country wares, batik, and horse-trading, with hundreds of locals dressed in their traditional bright Bai jackets, tunics, and plumed caps. column1: Southeast of the city is Thousand Buddha Mountain (Qianfoshan), but instead of a thousand Buddha images you’ll find a hundred today. [SEP] And, at only 280 m (about 900 ft) above sea level, it is more a hill than a “mountain.” [SEP] But a hike up the hill and down again permits a close look at old temples, grottoes with Buddhist statues, and refreshing forests. [SEP] Of all the springs in Jinan, the one with the most historical associations is the Jet Spring (Baotuquan). [SEP] It was from this spring in the 17th century that the Qing Dynasty Emperor Kangxi took a swig and pronounced it the “First Spring Under Heaven.” [SEP] It is now surrounded by a carefully landscaped park. [SEP] A short
column3: away is Black Tiger Spring (Heihuquan), its sweet water roaring from the mouths of three tigers carved in a black stone cliffside. [SEP] As the provincial capital, Jinan is the site of the Shandong Provincial Museum, where more than 400,000 items illustrate local history and nature. [SEP] The highlight of the collection is an exhibition of Longshan Black Pottery found near Jinan — an elegant, delicate ware fired 4,000 years ago.

[SEP] Or you can head south along Minzu Road and take in the life of the fishing boats and warehouses on the quays. [SEP] If you
column3: long enough (or hail a taxi), you end up at Nanputuo Temple, nestled in the hillside on the east shore of the harbor. [SEP] This Buddhist complex is in immaculate condition, its marble a gleaming white. [SEP] Locals are always on hand, burning incense and praying for good fortune. [SEP] The rocky cliffs behind the temple make for fine hiking and picnicking. [SEP] South of the temple and past Xiamen University (founded in 1921 by a local who made good in Singapore) is the Huli Mountain Cannon Platform. [SEP] In 1921 the Germans placed their artillery here to defend the colonial port of Amoy, as Xiamen was known to Westerners. [SEP] From here, if you look across the Formosa Strait on a sunny day, you can make out the disputed islands of Mazu and Jinmen. [SEP] Once known to Western politicians

[SEP] A good place to begin a tour is at Málaga’s principle landmark, Gibralfaro (from the Arabic Jebel al Faro — Lighthouse Hill). [SEP] Located some 130 m (425 ft) above the city, this hilltop is capped by the ramparts of a Phoenician castle reconstructed in the 14th century by the Moors (who went on to build the lighthouse that gave Gibralfaro its name). [SEP] The restored walls and parapets offer a superb panoramic view of both the city below and the coastline disappearing into the horizon. [SEP] Because it looks down on the Plaza de Toros, the hill also acts as free seating for bullfights taking place below. [SEP] Although it is possible to

[SEP] Back at sea level is the delightful Paseo del Parque, with contrasting fountains at either end, which connects the old town with the Plaza de Toros. [SEP] On its south side, it is a lush seaside tropical garden enhanced by fountains, duck ponds, and small bars. [SEP] The other side is home to the smaller Jardínes Puerta Oscura and two impressive buildings, the Ayuntamiento (Town Hall) and the 18th-century La Aduana (Old Custom House).

[SEP] A cobbled path climbs up the hillside within the walls to the portal dubbed Arco del Cristo (Gateway of Christ). [SEP] The victorious Christian army of Ferdinand and Isabella celebrated mass here when the fortress finally fell into their hands in 1487. [SEP] Higher still, the one-time palace (a disappointment compared with those in Granada and Sevilla) contains a small archaeological museum. [SEP] Beside the entrance to the Alcazaba are the partially excavated ruins of a Roman theater, the only visible remains of the ancient city. [SEP] A short

[SEP] The north tower soars 100 m (some 330 ft) above the street, but work on the other, a forlorn stump of stone, stopped in 1783 because of a lack of money. [SEP] Málaga was the birthplace of Pablo Ruiz Picasso, though the young artist left his native city at age 14 for the more cosmopolitan climates of Madrid and Barcelona. [SEP] The house he was born in, Casa Natal Picasso at Plaza de la Merced 14, doubles as a small museum and research center. [SEP] On a larger scale is the nearby Museo de Bellas Artes (Fine Arts Museum), an old Renaissance-style palace with pleasing patios. column1: Mijas Eight kilometers (5 miles) inland from Fuengirola and clinging to the hillside is Mijas. [SEP] Surrounded by modern villas and urbanizaciones (developments), it looks from the outside like any other quaint village with whitewashed houses. [SEP] But Mijas is different. [SEP] Most of the houses have been converted into upscale shops, restaurants, or bars, making the village itself a unique tourist attraction. [SEP] Traffic is banned from the center, so if you don’t feel like the short
column3: from the parking lot, take a mule taxi. [SEP] Mijas has Spain’s only square bullring, and across from it, beautifully tended gardens slope down to a cliff-top mirador, with fine views all along the coast. [SEP] There is another mirador beside the car park. [SEP] On one side of this natural balcony you will find a tiny chapel dedicated to the Virgen de la Peña (Our Lady of the Mountain), set in a grotto carved from living rock.

[SEP] Inside is a simple but elegant mosque that was later converted into a chapel dedicated to Santa María la Real. [SEP] Re-conquered by King Alfonso X in 1264, it became one of the most prosperous towns in Andalucía after the discovery of the Americas and the reunification of Spain in 1492. [SEP] Below the Alcázar lies the Colegiata (Collegiate Church), a towering dark stone cathedral dating from the 17th to 18th centuries. [SEP] Housed within is the precious image of Cristo de la Viña (Christ of the Vineyard). [SEP] It was the development of the sherry wine and brandy business that brought the city worldwide acclaim and more prosperity. [SEP] It is impossible to
column3: the streets without recognizing bodegas (wineries) of prestigious old firms such as Harvey, Williams & Humbert, Gonzalez-Byass, and Pedro Domecq. [SEP] As some of the names imply, it was a group of English merchants who launched Jerez as the world capital of fortified wine. [SEP] Three centuries on, their descendants continue to control the sherry trade. [SEP] All the larger companies offer tours of their bodegas, mostly on weekday mornings, and some require you to reserve in advance. [SEP] Traditional hospitality means of course that every tour ends with a tasting session.

column1: Iráklion was a thriving port in Minoan times and became known as Herakleium under Roman rule. [SEP] The arrival of the Venetians changed the town’s fortune. [SEP] They chose it as their capital, bestowing the name Candia on both the city and the whole island. [SEP] Candia blossomed with the riches of Venetian trade, and when Turkish forces stormed the island, the town held out for several months before falling into the Moslem hands. [SEP] It became a relative backwater of the Ottoman Empire only to rise to prominence again following union with Greece. [SEP] It was declared capital again in 1971, taking the title from Chaniá in the west. [SEP] The city center lies within the walls of a vast fortress started by the Venetians and reinforced by the Turks. [SEP] It is possible to
column3: along the walls, which seem to be swallowed up by the higher modern buildings of the city, to gain an impression of how large the citadel once was. [SEP] The heart of the city is tiny Venizélos Square (Plateía Venizélou) with its fringe of cafés and restaurants. [SEP] At its center, the Morosini Fountain dates from Venetian times, though the somber lion statues are three hundred years older. [SEP] Formerly waterspouts, these now stay dry. [SEP] They are now on view inside. [SEP] Head across 25 August Street to a small park — El Greco — named after the painter, a native of Crete, whose true name was Dominicos Theotokópoulos. [SEP] Here you can sit under the shade of the trees away from the noise of the traffic. [SEP] Continuing along 25 August Street leads to the waterfront and the majestic sight of the Venetian fortress (Koúles), built to protect the old harbor. [SEP] You’ll also see the vaulted remains of large arcaded asenali (ship repair yards) that serviced the Venetian fleet. [SEP] The fortress sits out on the breakwater and you will

column1: Immediately north of Venizélos Square you’ll reach 1866 Street (Odós 1866), also known as Market Street, which still has the atmosphere of an old Turkish bazaar. [SEP] Here you’ll be able to stroll past stalls selling fresh produce and souvenirs, or eat at the numerous small ouzeries that serve the market workers. [SEP] At the southern end of Market Street is Kornárou Square (Plateía Kornárou) where you will find the Bembo Fountain (Kríni Bembo) created in the 16th century using numerous pieces of architectural salvage — including the fine torso of a Greco-Roman statue. column3: from here to the left along the inner arterial road brings you to St. Catherine’s Square (Plateía Agías Ekaterínis) where the 19th-century Cathedral of Ághios Minás dwarfs two older religious buildings. [SEP] The small church immediately next to it is the Church of Ághios Minás, which has a splendid ornate iconostasis — if the church is closed ask in the cathedral as the custodian here has the key. [SEP] The lower floor here houses the throne room with ornate griffin frescoes and a lustral basin for ritual purification. [SEP] The gypsum throne is the oldest in Europe and traces of paint show that it would have been brightly colored when in use. [SEP] The walls — lined with stone seats thought to have been used by advisers or councilors — would have been decorated with red plaster and an ornamental dado. [SEP] Near the village of Agía Déka — named after ten saints who were martyred here — and widely scattered in farmland, are the remains of Górtis (Gortyn), capital of the island during the Roman era (from 65 b.c.) and also an important city in Minoan times. [SEP] Górtis is such a huge site — at its height it had a population of 300,000 — that you will see signposts to remains lying in the midst of crops south of the modern road. [SEP] Stop at the Byzantine church in the village — you’ll find stone from the ancient site used here too — and see the stone execution block of the martyrs. [SEP] Their tomb can be viewed through the gate of a nearby crypt. [SEP] The small settlements are almost ghostly silent save for the crochet needles of the old ladies or the clicking of old men’s worry beads at the kafenion. [SEP] Stop in Ágios Geórgios to visit the Folklore Museum and look for the remnants of hundreds of small windmills that once powered water pumps. [SEP] Now only a few still turn in the breeze, and irrigation is more high-tech. [SEP] On the southern edge of the plain is a large cave said to be the birthplace of Zeus — the Dictean Cave (Dictéon Ántron). [SEP] Though no proof can be put forward for this claim, from the ancient votives left in the cave it was certainly very important during Minoan times. [SEP] It is a 15-minute
column3: from the parking lot, or you can take a mule ride up the narrow path. [SEP] Be aware that the surface underfoot is very slippery, and take a flashlight for better visibility. [SEP] The cave drops precipitously 65 m (213 ft) into a dark cavern where the imagination begins to work overtime — what demons could lurk here? [SEP] A guide will help to point out details that your untrained eye might miss — such as the monstrous face of Kronos here to eat his new offspring Zeus, and the small nipple shaped stalagmites on which the infant god is said to have suckled. [SEP] The Dictean Cave is one of Crete’s most popular excursions and is very busy in the peak of the day. column1: Réthymnon has also been the intellectual center of Crete throughout the ages and still boasts a School of Philosophy. [SEP] In August each year it draws intellectuals and artists from across Greece for a Renaissance Festival. [SEP] The Old Town occupies a strategic position on a nub of land jutting out from the long flat coastline. [SEP] A huge fortress — the Fortezza — dominates the site, its walls rising high above the streets on the northwestern point. [SEP] This is thought to be the largest fortification ever built by the Venetians, who completed the task in 1586. [SEP] The finest views of the walls are from the promenade on the waterfront. [SEP] There is a small, whitewashed Orthodox chapel and the remains of barracks and arsenals. [SEP] Ottoman forces made surprisingly light work of taking the fortress in 1646. [SEP] They worshipped in a large mosque in the center of the fortress, whose interior you can explore. [SEP] Perhaps the most exciting part of the tour is the view over Réthymnon old town from the parapets on the eastern side — myriad tiled rooftops lead down to the harbor beyond. [SEP] Boats pick hikers up from the base of the Samariá Gorge and at busy times rows of tour buses await their return. [SEP] You can take boat trips to the island of Gávdos, the most southern territory in Europe, and to Loutró, a picturesque village with no vehicular access; or head inland on foot for Loutró and the remains of ancient Anópoli for an enjoyable day’s hiking. column1: and the Samariá Gorge The White Mountains (Lefká Óri) dominate the western part of the island. [SEP] The highest range on Crete, with several of its peaks breaking 2,000 m (5600 ft), there are no villages in its shadow because the mountains rise steeply with no perceptible foothills. [SEP] This is an untamed landscape, rugged and stunningly beautiful, with narrow valleys incised between limestone peaks that wear a mantle of snow until the early summer months. [SEP] Yet in spite of this the mountains host one of Crete’s most impressive, popular, and enjoyable excursions — the 16-km- (10-mile-)
column3: down the Samariá Gorge. [SEP] The gorge is the longest in Europe and starts in the heart of the mountains at a mighty 3,352 m (11,000 ft). [SEP] In winter its path carries melted water from the peaks above. [SEP] Only in the mild conditions of summer, when the torrent turns to a trickle, are people allowed to follow its path. [SEP] The journey brings home the true power and wonder of nature. [SEP] High walls of stone, ancient cypress trees, rare orchids, and soaring birds of prey can all be seen, along with glimpses of the wild Cretan goat — the kri-kri — bounding between precipitous crags.

[SEP] The abandoned village of Samariá, with its 14th-century church of Ossia Maria (Mary’s Bones), marks the halfway point. [SEP] People lived here until 1962; now there’s only a warden’s post and first-aid station. [SEP] Beyond is the gorge’s narrowest point, the Sideróportes (Iron Gates), only 3.5 m (11 ft) wide but 300 m (1,000 feet) high, a truly humbling sight and the most memorable, for from here the gorge opens up as it approaches the sea and is much less striking. [SEP] From Guadalest, the road leads to the small town of Callosa de Ensarriá, centre of the honey industry, where you can taste before you buy, often six or eight different flavours. [SEP] It’s easy to get away from crowds in this pleasant spot, but if you’re in the mood for company, you’ll find lots of people in the restaurants near the car park. [SEP] The next stop is Tárbena (10 km/6 miles farther along the C-3318), an invigorating mountain village famed for its delicious sausages. [SEP] They’re made from a secret recipe handed down to the present-day villagers by their Mallorcan ancestors, who came here in the early 17th century as part of an official repopulation scheme.

[SEP] The strangest of the cathedral’s treasures is contained in an urn here — the heart of Alfonso the Wise, bequeathed to Murcia by the 13th-century king long before his death. [SEP] Go out of the cathedral on the north side and

[SEP] But don’t look for bargains here; the name of this pedestrian thoroughfare belies the elegance of its shops. [SEP] At the north end you come upon the Casino (a private club, not a gambling establishment), with spirited turn-of-the century decor. [SEP] The entrance hall, an exact copy of the Hall of Ambassadors in Seville’s Alcázar, and the ladies’ lavatory — with its ceiling of cherubs — are the most magnificent rooms. [SEP] (Don’t forget a small tip to the steward who shows you around.) [SEP] At its eastern end, primary-colored buildings — a showcase of tragic splendor — seem to fall apart before your eyes. [SEP] Havana’s youth congregate along the Malecón on fine evenings, flying kites, necking, swimming off the rocks, and setting out to sea in giant inner tubes to fish. [SEP] Although most visitors will want to concentrate on historic and museum-like Old Havana, the newer districts provide a fascinating view of the areas where most people live and work. [SEP] The most interesting districts of New Havana are Central Havana and Vedado. [SEP] The former is a congested, lower-middle-class barrio with few attractions for visitors, although a
column3: along its dusty streets and crumbling façades can be an eye-opening experience. [SEP] Vedado is the city’s principal commercial and residential zone — the epicenter of middle-class Havana — with parks, monuments, hotels, restaurants, theaters, and the University of Havana. [SEP] Once the stomping grounds of the elite in the 1950s, the “suburb” of Miramar today is home to the offices of rich foreign companies investing in Cuba and the diplomatic missions of foreign governments. [SEP] Central Havana (Centro Habana)

[SEP] Opposite the tower-block Hotel Habana Libre — the Havana Hilton in pre-revolutionary days — is the Coppelia ice cream park. [SEP] At this institution, locals queue for hours for the prized ice cream, eating several scoops in one sitting or ladling them into saucepans to take home. [SEP] Hard-hearted foreigners paying in dollars down their scoops in a cordoned-off area. [SEP] Coppelia was instrumental in the award-winning Cuban film Fresa y Chocolate (“Strawberry and Chocolate”), a daring film about freedoms and revolutionary fervor in contemporary Havana (its title is a wry reference to the lack of choices of ice cream flavors — indeed, of all things — in Cuba). [SEP] A short
column3: up the hill brings you to the University of Havana, founded in the early 18th century, a quiet, attractive campus of neoclassical buildings. [SEP] English-speaking students eager to meet foreigners are numerous here. [SEP] Directly east on Calle San Miguel, between Calles Ronda and Mazón, is the fine and surprising Museo Napoleónico. [SEP] The mansion boasts not only Empire furniture but also a remarkable collection of Napoleonic memorabilia: busts, portraits, and even his pistol, hat, and death mask from St. Helena. [SEP] The house and contents were acquired by the state from a rich owner in 1960. [SEP] In the same year, the government acquired the Museo de Artes Decorativas, at Calle 17 between Calles D and E. [SEP] Behind the church is a great sea of crosses and marble saints in a picturesque cemetery; church officials claim it is wholly unrelated to travels that didn’t go so well. [SEP] A few blocks north, the Convento de Nuestra Señora del Carmen (from the early 19th century) was in a disastrous state in early 2000, though workers were busily rebuilding it. [SEP] Just enough of the structure remains to make plain that it would be stunning if carefully restored. [SEP] With the wooden statue in their grasp, they miraculously made it to shore. [SEP] Pilgrims, often making the last of the trek on their knees, pray to her image and place mementos and offerings of thanks for her miracles; among them are small boats and prayers for those who have tried to escape Cuba on rafts. [SEP] The Virgen is on the second floor, encased in glass and cloaked in a glittering gold robe. [SEP] If you’d like to stay overnight in this spectacular (and deathly peaceful) area, there is a hostal, Hospedería de la Caridad, behind the church, where foreigners who abide by the strict rules can stay for a mere five pesos a night (see page 133). [SEP] East of Santiago is Parque Baconao, a biosphere reserve spread over 40 km (25 miles). [SEP] The local dark-sand beaches can be scrubby and the hotels themselves are isolated, but there’s lots to explore in the park, and the Sierra de La Gran Piedra rise majestically above the coast.

[SEP] If you are trekking in the Annapurna region, you will at times have to give way to caravans of ponies, mules, and donkeys crowned with red and white yak-tail plumes. [SEP] In the Khumbu region, it will be caravans of yaks themselves (or yak-cow cross breeds) carrying the packs. column1: Solu-Khumbu: the Everest region (5 days–3 weeks). [SEP] The shortest possible trek for a close view of Mount Everest and Sherpa country in Sagarmatha National Park is a five-day dash with round-trip flights between Kathmandu and Lukla. [SEP] The trail goes up the Dudh Kosi river valley through lovely woodlands with an overnight at Phakding or Jorsale. [SEP] The next night is at Namche Bazaar, where there is a Sherpa market on Saturdays. [SEP] Return is by the same route with an added night at Lukla to be on hand for one of the (often cancelled) early morning flights back. [SEP] Add two days for the interesting switchback
column3: from Namche to the Thyangboche Monastery and back, or ten days for the circuit that goes on to Pheriche, Lobuje, Gorak Shep, and Kala Patar for one of the greatest of all Himalayan views. [SEP] It is also possible to continue on to the Everest Base Camp area at an exhausting 5,360 m (17,586 ft), although there is not much to see at base camp (no view of Everest). [SEP] Above this rises a tower of 13 diminishing golden disks symbolizing the 13 steps to enlightenment, then a golden royal parasol topped by a bell-shaped crown. [SEP] Strings of prayer flags stretch from the tower’s pinnacle, and around the base are hundreds of small prayer wheels. [SEP] While pilgrims circumambulate the stupa, monkeys, dogs, and pigeons clamber about and forage for scraps of food offerings in small altars set in the foundation. [SEP] The typical Nepali mix of Hinduism and Buddhism is almost immediately in evidence. [SEP] At the top of the stairs stands a huge dorje, the tantric thunderbolt symbol. [SEP] To the left of this (remember to
column3: clockwise around the stupa) rise two shikara-style votive towers to Hindu deities. [SEP] On the side of the stupa opposite the stairs is a very popular pagoda temple to Hariti Devi, a Hindu goddess who protects against smallpox and children’s diseases. [SEP] This temple, too, has Buddhist prayer wheels around it, worn shiny by the hands of the devout. [SEP] Adjacent to this temple, within a cage to prevent their theft, are two images alternately described as the White Tara and the Green Tara (Buddhist deities) and as Ganga and Jamuna (Hindu deities). [SEP] A bronze peacock accompanies these two figures. [SEP] There is a small forest of white chaitya shrines behind the Hariti Devi temple, and a porch to one side where pilgrims congregate to prepare meals in offering for the goddess.

[SEP] Nagarkot, which stands on the crest of a ridge at 2,195 m (7,200 ft), is about an hour’s drive from Bhaktapur and one of the best places in the Kathmandu area for viewing the Himalayas. [SEP] From this aerie on the rim of the Kathmandu Valley, 322 km (200 miles) of the Himalayas stretch out before you in an immense wall of rock and ice. column1: Geographically if not temperamentally part of the Left Bank, the Palais-Bourbon is the seat of the Assemblée Nationale (parliament). [SEP] Designed for a daughter of Louis XIV in 1722, it makes a stately riverside façade for the 7th arrondissement, with its 18th-century embassies, ministries, and private mansions (hôtels particuliers). [SEP] Napoléon added the Grecian columns facing the Pont de la Concorde, but the palace is more graceful seen from its entrance on the south side. [SEP] Access is available only on written request or invitation by a deputy. [SEP] A privileged few get to see the great Délacroix paintings in the library, illustrating the history of civilization. [SEP] Then the Invalides came to symbolize the glory of Napoléon himself, when his remains were finally brought back from St. Helena in 1840 for burial in the chapel under the golden Dôme. [SEP] The church remains deliberately preserved as an atmospheric ruin. [SEP] After a short distance you’ll arrive at the western wall and a small square, Plazuela de la Rogativa, with a bronze statue commemorating the torchlight religious procession, or rogativa, that saved the city in 1797. [SEP] It’s believed that the lights held by the bishop and the women of the city fooled the British forces in the bay into assuming that Spanish reinforcements had arrived. [SEP] The British fled empty-handed. [SEP] Just a short
column3: north of the square is the Casa Blanca (White House), which for 250 years was the home of the descendants of Ponce de León. [SEP] Something of a mini-fortress, safe behind its own high wall, the house itself is fascinating — the interior is a museum to life in 16th- and 17th-century San Juan, with many rooms full of period furniture. [SEP] Walk back toward the Plazuela de la Rogativa and peer over the city wall, which rises over 100 ft (301⁄2 m) at this point. [SEP] The plain façade is broken by the San Juan Gate, which was once the only entrance to the city from the old port. [SEP] The gate was constructed in 1639, and the walls were completed in 1641. [SEP] The army used to drill here, hence the name (armas means weapons, or arms), but today it is simply a place for people to meet and have a coffee, or sit and chat. [SEP] Workers enjoy picnic lunches here at midday; old people while away the afternoon. [SEP] The Alcaldía has an interesting interior, with checkerboard marble floors and magnificent chandeliers. [SEP] It’s usually open on weekdays; you can check with the tourist information office on the ground floor as to whether it’s OK to wander around. [SEP] Back on Calle Fortaleza,

[SEP] A fine example of an 18th-century house, it is now the Museum of the Puerto Rican Family, full of the furniture, toys, and other daily artifacts of a well-to-do San Juan family. [SEP] Taking a left out of the museum brings you back to Plaza Colón, from where you can make your way south toward San Juan harbor. [SEP] Along the way you’ll pass Teatro Tapia (Tapia Theater) named after Puerto Rican playwright Alejandro Tapia y Rivera. [SEP] The splendid façade was restored in 1976, the interior remodeled in 1987. [SEP] The theater hosts regular performances of ballet, dance, and drama, often showcasing works by modern Puerto Rican writers and choreographers.

column1: Culebra, much smaller at 21 sq miles (34 sq km), is north of Vieques. [SEP] It is the largest rock in a collection of over twenty that attract sailors and divers from the main island. [SEP] Culebra was known as the Spanish Virgin Island until the American takeover — it lies halfway between Puerto Rico and St. Thomas in the US Virgin Islands. [SEP] Its only town is named Dewey, after Admiral George Dewey, a hero of the American-Spanish War of 1898. [SEP] The local people are more apt to call it Pueblo. [SEP] Culebra is full of natural beauty: beaches (Flamenco is the most celebrated), clear waters full of marine life, and land awash with flowers. [SEP] Most people come just to sit on the beach or
column3: in the fresh air. [SEP] Much of the island is now managed by the US Fish and Wildlife Service, to preserve the environment. [SEP] It makes an interesting day trip from Puerto Rico and a total contrast to hot days in the streets of Old San Juan. [SEP] The Southeast

[SEP] Hundreds of careworn buildings were brought back to life, and power cables were buried underground and out of sight. [SEP] Along with this physical transformation came a cultural change: Ponce has become a focus for social events that celebrate Puerto Rican history and tradition; several major festivals are held here throughout the year. [SEP] The focus of the city is Parque Degetau in Plaza Las Delicias (Delight Square), known by most locals as Plaza de Ponce. [SEP] Most of what you want to see is within a few minutes’
column3: of this plaza, and cafés and restaurants for refreshments are also near at hand. [SEP] You can spend a wonderful morning just soaking in the atmosphere. [SEP] The park, with its shady trees, cooling fountains, and somber bronze statues, including one of Luis Muñoz Marín, is where people come to take a break from the midday heat. [SEP] Work on the fort began in 1671, to protect the harbor. [SEP] The terra-cotta walls, pretty painted shutters, and crenellated clock tower give the building a cozy rather than a fearsome look. [SEP] The interior has been transformed into a museum of life in the US Virgin Islands: colonial furniture, archive documents, and old photographs of the islands, people, and towns. [SEP] Take a

column1: Perhaps one of the most beautiful and unusual buildings in Charlotte Amalie is the St. Thomas Synagogue, on Crystal Gade. [SEP] This is the oldest synagogue building in continual use under the American flag. [SEP] The Jewish congregation has always been strong here, from the very earliest days of Danish settlement in 1655. [SEP] When the all-consuming fire of 1831 broke out, 64 families were worshipping in the small synagogue. [SEP] Only one scroll could be saved before the flames destroyed the building. [SEP] The present structure was built on the same spot and opened in 1833. [SEP] The synagogue has sand on the floor, symbolic of the Jewish flight from Egypt.
